generalInformation.description: The top and the sides of this sundial's spherical dial face are broken off. The base is decorated with a high relief of a boat and a man's head in the middle. On the Eastern and Western plane of the corpus two antae emerge from the upper part of the sundial, with a cornice in the upper third. A decorative tripartite element with a convex middle part protrudes from below the dial face.

dialfaces.description: The spherical shadow-receiving-shell is tipped up on end between two antae at an angle of about 27° from vertical. Although the top and sides are broken away, hour lines 3 through 9 can be seen extending from the winter solstice across the equinox to the summer solstice.

Kommentar: Found in 1931 during agricultural work in the Altino area.

generalInformation.description: A fragment of a spherical sundial with remains of at least three different inscriptions.

dialfaces.description: Parts of three hour lines and three day curves are preserved on this fragment of spherical surface. Three inscriptions can be found on the dialface on the daycurves.
dialfaces.inscriptions: Equinox:  [ἰση] μη [ρία]  above summer solstice:  ἐ’ωα ἐπι[τολή]  below summer solstice:  [τρ]οπαὶ θϵ [ριναί], as restored by Dürrbach and Tannery. Another inscription on the winter solstice is assumed:   [τροπαὶ χϵιμϵριναί] .

generalInformation.inscriptions: Equinox:  [ἰση] μη [ρία]  above summer solstice:  ἐ’ωα ἐπι[τολή]  below summer solstice:  [τρ]οπαὶ θϵ [ριναί].  The destroyed winter solstice curve probably carried  the following inscription:   [τροπαὶ χϵιμϵριναί] .

Kommentar: The Greek inscriptions on the day curves have been restored by Dürrbach and Tannery as follows: Equinox:  [ἰση] μη [ρία]  above summer solstice:  ἐ’ωα ἐπι[τολή]  below summer solstice:  [τρ]οπαὶ θϵ [ριναί]. The destroyed winter solstice curve probably carried the following inscription:  [τροπαὶ χϵιμϵριναί] . Found on July 9, 1903, in the Agora of the Delians on Delos, Greece. (Construction in the agora using blue marble began in the third century B.C.) The arrangement of the plates in Deonna suggests that this fragment is on the island of Delos. [...] (Gibbs 1976)

generalInformation.description: A tufa-sundial, once completely covered with stucco, without any additional ornaments, besides of traces of red colour in the winter solstice line. It is broken in the centre.

dialfaces.description: A break at the center of the dial has destroyed all of the meridian and parts of the fifth and seventh hour lines. All of the other hour lines and three day curves remain incised in the plaster coating. [...] Some hour lines extend into the area above this solstice.

Kommentar: Gibbs: SD seen at the portico storage room

generalInformation.description: The sundial has plain sides. A torus moulding connects the oblique upper and lower front parts.

dialfaces.description: Complete bronze gnomon in position in the top surface of the dial. [...] Ten hour lines and three engraved day curves are visible in the photograph.

generalInformation.description: A simple upper part is connected to a high base by an oblong, set back part with sloping edges. The base is decorated with two stylized knobbly animal legs, ending in a circular shape, from which spring four vertical, abstract, drop-shaped animal toes.

material.materialSubcategory: Gibbs: brownish creamy stone; Schaldach: marble
material.materialName: Gibbs: brownish creamy stone; Schaldach: marble

dialfaces.description: Eleven engraved hour lines divide six engraved day curves including one which coincides with the lower edge of the spherical surface. ´[...]
dialfaces.inscriptions: Around dial face:  [Πἁδας ὣ] ρας Διο [γ] éν [ης ταῖσ]. On sloping front:  ‘Εννéα Μοúδαισ.  Under slope:  [τ] ó [νσ] ϵ τòν ἡμéριον, Νϵικομ´η ὁησ, κáμνϵς ‘Αρ´ητῃ.   Between legs:   [Φ] ιλῶν, Φíλϵ, ἐ βíδκοπον ϵὐγνῶμονá μ’ἠοῦς ϵ ‘íδατο Διο γéνης οἰσι δδμοις κτé[α]ν[ον].

generalInformation.inscriptions: Around dial face:  [Πἁδας ὣ] ρας Διο [γ] éν [ης ταῖσ].    On sloping front:  ‘Εννéα Μοúδαισ.  Under slope:  [τ] ó [νσ] ϵ τòν ἡμéριον, Νϵικομ´η ὁησ, κáμνϵς ‘Αρ´ητῃ. citations: \cite{Schaldach2006}, p.142; CD, 43 a, b, c, d, e.

Kommentar: http://www.panoramio.com/user/2711353/tags/1004%20Kavalla Bilder KS Fuhre 7 unter BSDP0770 - allerdings nur Genehmigung für KS 1. Buch, dort Nr. 43. Gibbs says seen in Museum of Kavala, now in Komotini?

generalInformation.description: A half-cylinder molding separates the spherical surface from the sloping base.

dialfaces.description: The gnomon hole is preserved in the top surface of the dial. [...]  The dial is cracked from the top to the bottom near the meridian. All eleven hour lines continue from the gnomon to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface. No day curves are visible.

generalInformation.description: A gnomon hole (20 x 50) in the top surface contains no metal.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend from the gnomon hole to the lower edge of the spherical surface. No day curves are visible.

generalInformation.description: The sundial has no visible ornaments. Front and lower part are oblique, the sides seem to be plain.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines and an equinox are preserved. The summer solstice may coincide with the lower edge; the winter solstice may coincide with the boundary of the broken area at the top.

generalInformation.description: The design of this limestone sundial is simple. The base and back seem to have suffered some damage.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend between the winter solstice and the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface. Two engraved day curves are visible.

generalInformation.description: This tall sundial has no ornamental elements on the sides. Its opposingly inclined upper and lower front part are connected by a semi-circular moulding (torus). Gibbs:  Seen in the Museo Borgiano in 1798.

dialfaces.description: Eleven engraved hour lines extend from the winter solstice to the summer solstice and are crossed by the equinoctial day curve. [...] Antonini´s drawing shows a preserved gnomon.

Kommentar: Seen in the Museo Borgiano in 1798.

generalInformation.description: The upper part of the sundial is very damaged. The front part is rather large in comparison to the lower part, the horizontal dividing line decorated with two symmetrical, duckpin-shaped objects meeting in the middle and ending in a narrow cylinder on the outer edge. There is no real base; this part of the sundial rejuvenates in a right angle and is smaller than the lowermost area of the lower part. Gibbs: Seen in the Villa Borgis, Velletri, Italy, in 1798.

dialfaces.description: The top surface of the dial is damaged so that only nine hour lines are preserved. Parts of three engraved day curves (equidistant from each other and the lower edge) are visible.

Kommentar: Seen in the Villa Borgis, Velletri, Italy, in 1798.

generalInformation.description: The FrontUP is bordered by an embossed margin, also following the shape of the dial face's curve. The base part is very low. Gibbs: Located in the Casa de Angelis, Tivoli, Italy, in 1798.

dialfaces.description: Note that the eleven engraved hour lines are not crossed by an engraved equinox, but extend from the winter solstice to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface.

generalInformation.description: A sundial with no visible decorative elements. It has no base, the oblique frontLP ends on the floor. Gibbs: Found at the Osteria di Ponte Lucano near Tivoli. In 1798, part of the collection of Thomas F. Hill, England.

dialfaces.description: Thirteen engraved hour lines (two near the horizon) are visible radiating from a gnomon hole. An engraved equinox and summer solstice are also visible.

generalInformation.description: The sundial seems to have no additional decoration, except for the protruding front part of the base. Gibbs: Seen at the Casa Beschi, Tivoli, Italy, in 1798.

dialfaces.description: Eleven engraved hour lines extend from the engraved winter solstice across the engraved equinox to the summer solstice which coincides with the lower edge.

generalInformation.description: The sundial's planes are undecorated. Its base is rather high. Gibbs: Seen in Terracina (ancient Tarracina), Italy, in 1798.

dialfaces.description: Eleven engraved hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across the winter solstice and the equinox to the lower edge of the dial face. The summer solstice curve coincides with this lower edge.

generalInformation.description: The sundial seems to have no decorative elements. Gibbs: Found in the Villa Equitis de Blasus Aloysii and placed in the cathedral in 1891.

A torus moulding connects the two oblique front parts. There are two oblong shallow vertical rectangles forming stylized legs. Severino: Scheda del museo redatta nel 1949: Quadrante solare con segnato nell’incavo, che è parte di emisfera, le linee verticali delle ore e orizzontali dei solstizi. Poggia su una base che presenta un foro nella parte anteriore e che si allarga in basso, limitata sulla faccia anteriore, ai lati da due larghe fasce verticali. In alto è l’incasso dello gnomone. Marmo bianco lunense con superficie corrosa, scheggiato lievemente allo spigolo in alto a sinistra, entrambi gli angoli superiori sono formati da frammenti riattaccati. Superficie con scalfiture e abrasioni.

dialfaces.description: The surface is badly worn in the area of the winter solstice, but it is possible to estimate the position of the curve. Eleven hour lines continue to the top of the dial but do not meet at the gnomon hole. [...] The third, sixth, and ninth hour lines bear markings as shown in the diagram at right.

generalInformation.description: The planes of the corpus are undecorated.

dialfaces.description: A gnomon hole in the top surface is 30 mm x 17 mm. All eleven hour lines continue from the gnomon hole to the summer solstice. Three engraved day curves are visible. The engraved summer solstice coincides with the lower edge of the spherical surface. The winter solstice curve from hour 0 to hour XII is divided into the following arcs: 9, 11, 13.5, 13, 13.5, 13, 12.8, 13.5, 13.4, 13, 13.5, 8.5mm. The equinox curve in divided into the following arcs: 21, 27.7, 28.2, 26, 24, 24, 24, 25, 27, 28.2, 27.7, 21 mm.

generalInformation.note: Donated by John Savile, 1st Baron Savile of Rufford. Department: Greek & Roman Antiquities, registration number: 1893, 0713.13.

generalInformation.description: The head of a bearded man with a hat can be seen in the middle of the frontLP. A theory suggests that this is Berosus, the supposed inventor of the sundial. Gibbs: According to reports the bust was found near the excavated dial and appeared to belong where it is now placed. Found at Palestrina before 1787.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines divide three day curves. There are also lines running across the dial. These show the seasons with the middle line halfway between the highest point (midsummer) and its lowest point (midwinter).

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: The sundial is unadorned, but there are some construction lines visible on the top.

dialfaces.description: Only light traces of hour lines and day curves can be seen on the shadow receiving surface. However, deeply engraved construction lines are clearly visible in the top and front surfaces. One straight line marks the meridian on the oblique front. At the top left, two lines have been engraved parallel to the back edge. The first is 68 mm from this back edge and the second is 45 mm from the first. A single line 68 mm from the back edge and also parallel to it is preserved at the top left. The traces of day curves visible on the shadow-receiving surface seem to coincide with these engraved guide lines at the top edge.

generalInformation.note: Collocazione definitiva: Granai del Foro I St. A 1 B 1.

Kommentar: The gnomon hole in the top surface is 49.5 mm deep.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: A tapering gnomon groove, 34 mm wide at the top, 14 mm wide at the bottom, and 32 mm deep pierces the top surface. [...] Found along the Via di Nola, Region V, Insula III, no. 6.

material.materialSubcategory: Gibbs: gray porous stone, Severino: tufo
material.materialName: Gibbs: gray porous stone, Severino: tufo

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend between engraved solstice lines and are crossed by the equinox. The day curves ate equidistant from each other and the lower edge. In the oblique front of the dial a single engraved line follows the curve of the circular section 20 mm from the lower edge. A small round hole is visible in the right side.

generalInformation.note: Found along the Via di Nola, Region V, Insula III, no. 6.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: The sundial's top and sides are heavily damaged. Starting on the upper part of sides of the frontLP, there are two legs with cyma recta profiles.

dialfaces.description: The top and sides are broken. Parts of eight hour lines are visible but no engraved day curves are preserved.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: The FrontUP of this sundial is decorated with a rosette on both sides and a lying crescent in the middle. The frontUP and LP are connected by a torus moulding. Hourline 3, 6 and 9 have been painted with red paint. Gibbs: A rectangular gnomon hole, 24 mm wide, lies in the narrow center of the top surface close to the top front edge.

dialfaces.description: Two engraved solstices limit the extent of the hour lines which are crossed by an equinox engraved always equidistant from both solstices and the lower edge

generalInformation.note: Collocazione definitiva: D III 2 C.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: The planes of this tufa-sundial are unadorned. The right half was thought to be lost in 1960, but apparently reappeared. Gibbs: A copper gnomon now in position at the top of the dial is a restoration. However, visible lead traces are probably original.

dialfaces.description: Seven hour lines (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7) and part of three day curves are preserved. A trace of red color can be seen at the junction of the meridian and the equinox.

generalInformation.note: The dial was complete in 1960; now the right half is lost.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: Except for a torus moulding between the frontUP and LP, the design of this sundial is rather simple. Gibbs: The base of a bronze gnomon remains in a lead filled gnomon hole in the top surface of the dial. Traces of red orange color remain in the eleven hour lines and three day curves. [...] Bronze and lead remain in the mount hole in the bottom surface.  Severino: Sul "top" dell'orologio si vede bene la base rimanente dello gnomone che in questo caso non è conservato. Il tracciato orario conserva solo 10 linee orarie e le curve dei solstizi ed equinozi ed è fatto con buona cura. Nessun colore si evince sulla superficie e nessun rilievo o iscrizione.

material.materialName: white marble with streaks of gray

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: None of the hour lines extend beyond either solstice. Severino: Sul "top" dell'orologio si vede bene la base rimanente dello gnomone che in questo caso non è conservato. Il tracciato orario conserva solo 10 linee orarie e le curve dei solstizi ed equinozi ed è fatto con buona cura. Nessun colore si evince sulla superficie e nessun rilievo o iscrizione.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: A rounded gnomon hole in the top surface is 25 mm deep.

dialfaces.description: All eleven hour lines and the three day curves have been deeply engraved in the tufa. Traces of dark red color emphasize the hour lines which extend beyond both solstice curves.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: This sundial's limbus is set off by a thin line. There is a pinkish colour in all of the hourlines and daycurves. The same colour is visible in the area above the winter solstice and the front part of the base. Gibbs: A gnomon hole 34 mm deep remains in the top surface of the dial.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: This sundial has no ornaments in relief. Its frontLP and base are broken away, therefore the original ratio is undistinguishable. The hourlines and two daycurves were filled with red colour. Gibbs: The original gnomon hole has been filled by a restorer, and a thin wire gnomon has been inserted.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines emphasized with dark red color extend from the gnomon hole to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface. The same dark red color con be seen in the engraved winter solstice and equinox.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

site.siteSpecific: Casa del Menandro, Reg. I, Ins. 10

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines continue from the gnomon groove to the lower edge. Two engraved day curves are visible.

generalInformation.note: The house dates from the period between 80 B.C. and 14 A.D.

site.siteSpecific: Regio III, Casa di MM. Obellii Firmi

generalInformation.description: This sundial's top and sides are broken off. Some kind of cornice conncts the frontLP with the base, which reflects in a similar shape at the base of the sundial. Gibbs: The house dates from the period between 30 B.C. and 32 A.D.

material.materialName: tufa, covered with red painted stucco

dialfaces.description: No color is preserved on the dial face. Only seven hour lines (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9) and an engraved equinox are visible.

generalInformation.note: The house dates from the period between 30 B.C. and 32 A.D.

archive.holderInstitution: Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Napoli e Pompei

generalInformation.description: The sundial consists of two fragments. The right half was already known to Gibbs in 1976, the left half reappeared in 2005. Once covered with stucco, the left half has almost none of it left and is badly damaged, whereas on the right one some time indicating lines are still visible, as well as some traces of red colour on the base. On top, a construction line has been engraved.  First fragment, Gibbs: Preserved portions of the gnomon hole indicate a depth of 28 mm.  Second fragment, Severino: Questo frammento è stato ritrovato da Peppino Cesarano, assistito da Ciro Sicignano, il 17 marzo del 2005, in seguito alla mia visita a Pompei. I due funzionari della Soprintendenza, soggiogati dal fascino delle meridiane, hanno prestato attenzione ai nuovi ritrovamenti degli scavi attualmente aperti ed hanno trovato questo frammento di meridiana, probabilmente conica, in pietra calcare. Lo hanno inventariato e spostato nel deposito di Casa Bacco. Alt. 14,5 cm; base 11,5 cm; lunghezza 39 cm.

dialfaces.description: A construction guide line engraved in the top surface is clearly visible parallel to the back edge at a distance of 97 mm. Only half of the shadow-receiving surface is preserved. On it, five hour lines (7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and two day curves (winter solstice and equinox) can be seen engraved in the stucco. The top guide line does not meet the winter solstice line, although the two lines intersect the top edge very near to each other.

generalInformation.note: Collocazione definitiva: Granai del Foro I St. A 1 B 1.

generalInformation.description: The upper part of this sundial is in a bad state. The intersection between the frontUP and LP is decorated with a protruding torus (?) moulding, almost like a cornice, transitioning into a concave lower plane.
The sundial is unadorned and of broad and low dimensions.

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: None of the eleven hour lines continue beyond either solstice. The equinox is always equidistant from the solstice curves and from the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface. Severino: Il Dr. Peppino Cesarano, funzionario della Soprintendenza di Pompei, e' andato ad indagare per nostro conto ad Ercolano sull'esistenza di queste meridiane. Ha trovato, infatti, la meridiana di cui sopra che, per quanto concerne la descrizione della conca sferica e delle linee orarie si trova in accordo con la scheda n° 1031G di Gibbs che pero' la colloca nella "Casa dell'Atrio a Mosaico", mentre questa ha provenienza sconosciuta e le misure non concordano con quelle di Gibbs. Una discrepanza difficilmente risolvibile. In accordo con la scheda Gibbs, la meridiana presenta tracce di nove linee orarie con il particolare non molto comune che tutte si prolungano oltre la curva del solstizio invernale fino alla base dove era collocato lo gnomone. Purtroppo la Gibbs nulla dice per quanto riguarda la forma del reperto oltre al fatto che rileva essere in marmo bianco, mentre questa è in tufo.

generalInformation.description: The horizontal section of the gnomon hole is a narrow rectangle 25 mm x 6 mm. The eleven hour lines do not continue beyond either solstice. Three engraved day curves are visible.  A half-cylinder molding separates the oblique front surface from the sloping base.

dialfaces.description: The eleven hour lines do not continue beyond either solstice. Three engraved day curves are visible.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: The gnomon hole is 17 mm deep. The top left corner is broken away.

dialfaces.description: Nine hour lines are visible. Only the meridian continues beyond the winter solstice to the gnomon hole. Three day curves are preserved.

generalInformation.description: This sundial's design is simple and unardorned. Gibbs: A gnomon hole, 30 mm in diameter, is visible in the top surface of the dial.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines cross there day curves. The length of the hour lines is limited by the solstice curves.

generalInformation.note: The object could be identified with object 434 in the database. Gibbs suggests siteID 280 as site, the site idenfitication 231=Villa Tuscolana/Villa Rufinella comes from \cite{Severino_Adam2004}, p. 74. Gibbs: This dial should possibly identified with that published by Luca Zuzzeri in 1746.

generalInformation.description: A kneeling, bearded, naked male figure, that can securely be identified as Atlas, is supporting the spherical upper part on his arms.

dialfaces.description: Eleven engraved hour lines radiate from a small engraved circular arc near the gnomon hole. The lines cross three engraved parallel circles. The third, sixth, and ninth hour lines extend to the lower edge of the dial face.

generalInformation.description: The green and rusty gnomon now in place is probably not original. HoweThe curve of the dialface is emphasized by a (slightly protruding) lip. Two low-relief, oblong legs flank the base. Gibbs: The green and rusty gnomon now in place is probably not original. However, beneath the ring base of the present gnomon there is a hole which may have held the original gnomon. ver, beneath the ring base of the present gnomon there is a hole which may have held the original gnomon. Travertine marble, white  Stylized legs in low relief flank the base. A 12 mm wide lip follows the edge of the front circular section. Eleven hour lines divide three day curves.

dialfaces.description: A 12 mm wide lip follows the edge of the front circular section. Eleven hour lines divide three day curves.

generalInformation.note: Found in Castelnuovo, Italy, on  the Via Flaminia in 1751. Pope Benedict XIV restored the gnomon and fixed it in position.

generalInformation.description: This sundial’s lower front part and base are broken off. Two low-relief rosettes with six petals flank the upper front part, while a horizontal crescent is carved in the middle. Gibbs: A damaged gnomon hole is visible at the top above the meridian.

dialfaces.description: Of all eleven hour lines, only the meridian continues to the gnomon hole. The three day curves are parallel to each other.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: A rectangular gnomon hole is preserved in the center of the top surface of the dial.

dialfaces.description: Three parallel day curves and eleven hour lines form the usual grid. All hour lines continue beyond the winter solstice to the gnomon.

generalInformation.description: The sundial has a rounded back and no additional ornaments.

dialfaces.description: Except for the only partially broken off sides, the hourlines and daycurves are in very good condition. (seen July 2014) Gibbs: Although both sides are broken away, parts of eleven hour lines remain to divide three day curves.

generalInformation.description: This miniature sundial has a rounded back. Some engraved letters below the dialface surface are still traceable (see 3D-model, e.g. ending area of hourline 3). Gibbs: A gnomon groove 5 mm wide remains in the top surface of the dial.

dialfaces.description: Twelve hour lines extend from a day curve near the gnomon to the lower edge of the spherical surface.

generalInformation.note: Found at Naukratis in 1883. Museum Department: Greek & Roman Antiquities. Registration number: 1886, 0401.1477. Note in Petrie´s journal describes the object as 'a small limestone dial was picked out of the rubbish' in the area of the Temple of Apollo (Tagebücher von 1885(?), p. 191.).

generalInformation.description: The upper and lower front part are connected by a torus moulding. On the frontUP is a two-rowed neopunic inscription, which helps dating the sundial to the 1st century CE.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extending between two day curves are visible in the sketch by L. Janin.

generalInformation.description: The right third of this spherical sundial is broken off. The remains seem unadorned.

dialfaces.description: The meridian line extends  from the gnomon hole to the bottom of the base. Other preserved hour lines extend from the winter to the summer solstice. There is no engraved equinox curve.

generalInformation.description: The right half of this sundial remains in two fragments, the left half has been reconstructed. Its lower front plane is indented by an oblong rectangle.

dialfaces.description: Five hour lines and three day curves are visible in the published photograph.

generalInformation.description: Only the right half of this sundial remains. The lower front part and base are missing. The limbus was emphasized by a thin protruding lip.

archive.holderInstitution: National Museum of Romanian History (Muzeul Național de Istorie a României)

generalInformation.description: Only a small fragment remains.

material.notes: Found at Istropolis on the Black Sea.

dialfaces.description: Only a fragment of the shadow-receiving surface of this dial is preserved; but on it, two hour lines, including meridian, are visible. The equinox and the summer solstice day curves can also be seen as well as part of a triangle having vertex at the winter solstice curve and the meridian as axis.  [...] Ionescu-Carligel calculates φ to be 44°31'.
dialfaces.inscriptions: Greek inscription is preserved along the triangle line:  ὀσ] χρ’ο [νοσ]    Thirteen short lines marked with the Greek letters  ᾿ [α]   through   ᾿ [ν]     divide the meridian between winter and summer solstices.

generalInformation.inscriptions: Greek inscription is preserved along the triangle line:  ὀσ] χρ’ο[νοσ]    Thirteen short lines marked with the Greek letters   [α]  through    [ν]  divide the meridian between winter and summer solstices.

citations: \cite{Ionescu-Carligel1969}, p. 199 ff, figures 1, 2 and p. 206 f, figure 5.
\cite{Ionescu-Carligel1970}, p. 121 ff, figure 2 and p. 134 ff, figures 10, 11.

generalInformation.description: Eine Säule aus weisslichem Luxemburger Sandstein von 37 cm Höhe bei 32 cm Durchmesser, auf deren Basis der Buchstabe H (=horologium?) eingehauen, und deren Schaft in eigenartiger, einen borkigen Eichenstamm nachahmender Weise kanelliert ist. Die Oberfläche zeigt Spuren von Mörtel, durch welchen sie vereinigt war mit der Unterseite einer runden Platte, ebenfalls aus Luxemburger Sandstein, zur grössten Hälfte erhalten. Die unterschiedliche Dicke bedingt eine mässige Neigung des Zifferblattes nach vorne (vgl. Fig. 4). An der Peripherie der Platte sind drei fast konzentrische Kurven, mit den in Zwischenräumen von 47 mm gestellten Zahlzeichen VII-XI, eingegraben; zentrales, rundes Loch zur Aufnahme des stiftförmigen Sonnen- oder Schattenzeigers gnomon.

dialfaces.description: An der Peripherie der Platte sind drei fast konzentrische Kurven, mit den in Zwischenräumen von 47 mm gestellten Zahlzeichen VII-XI, eingegraben; zentrales, rundes Loch zur Aufnahme des stiftförmigen Sonnen- oder Schattenzeigers „gnomon“.
dialfaces.inscriptions: Zahlzeichen VII-XI.

generalInformation.description: This hemispherical sundial was found in 1908 in the ruins of a roman villa in France. The report of the discovery does not mention any ornamental decoration. Gibbs: Traces of a gnomon hole are visible in the top surface of the dial above the meridian.

dialfaces.description: Although both sides are broken, eleven engraved hour lines and two engraved day curves are preserved. The summer solstice coincides with the lower edge of the spherical surface.

generalInformation.description: The knowledge about this sundial is only based on a sketch from L. Janin. The sundial he drew has a protruding broad lip following the curve of the dialface, some kind of (torus?) moulding/cornice at the transition between frontUP and LP and similar design elements at the foot of the high base. It can be dated to before the 3rd century AD because of its reuse in the Vienna Gate in Gratianopolis, the modern Grenoble.

dialfaces.description: Measurements and sketch from L. Janin.

archive.holderDepartment: Private collection of Father J. Giry

generalInformation.description: This spherical sundial has no additional visible adornment. Gibbs: A well-preserved bronze gnomon is in position in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. [...] Found at Quarante among the ruins of Roman villas dating from the third or fourth century A. D.

dialfaces.description: A well-preserved bronze gnomon is in position in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. Eleven well-traced hour lines and three day curves divide the shadow receiving surface. [...] Janin measures a latitude of 37 with obliquity of ecliptic equal to 24.

generalInformation.note: Gibbs: Measurements and sketch sent to me by L. Janin, Sevres, France, on February 9, 1971.

archive.holderInstitution: National Museum of Romanian History (Muzeul Național de Istorie a României)

generalInformation.description: A gnomon hole (27 mm long x 15 mm wide x 49 mm deep) is preserved in the back of the dial with a 20 mm wide groove in the top surface. [...] Two hands and a damaged head support the rounded sides, back and bottom of the dial surface. G. Bordenache dates workmanship to the third century A.D. I

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend from the winter solstice across the equinox to the lower edge. A twelfth lightly scratched hour line runs parallel to the meridian 4.5 mm to the right. [...] onescu-Carligel calculates the latitude of the dial to be 44.15.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Four standing figures decorate the base. Found at the village of Bettwiller in the spring of 1879. The style of the sculpture dates from the second century A.D. Bogaers: Bestossener Stein vierseitig mit Reliefs bearbeitet. Vorn als Trägerin der Zeit unter der Sonnenuhr eine unbekleidete Tänzerin (Hore?). Rückseite: Unbekleideter Mercur mit Schlangenstab in der Linken. In der Rechten, vor dem Unterleib gehalten, der Geldbeutel. Links: Apoll (?) mit langem auf die Schulter herabfallendem Haar. In der Linken, die auf dem Leib liegt, ein nicht erkennbares Attribut; in der Rechten eine Schlange als Zeichen seiner im keltischen Raum weit verbreiteten Funktion als Heilgott. Rechts: Bärtige Gestalt in Tanzbewegung mit über dem Kopf geschwungenem Gewand.

material.materialName: streaked sandstone from the Vosges Mountains

dialfaces.description: Three engraved day curves are visible. Possibly a fourth day curve coincided with the lower edge of the spherical shadow-receiving surface. The meridian and two other hour lines extend from the first day curve to the lower edge. Between the third day curve and the lower edge, the areas between major hour lines are each divided into three parts, so that  twelve hours are marked in all.

generalInformation.note: Kat. Strasbourg Nr. 18 and Arachne 18612.

generalInformation.description: The gnomon hole is 29 mm deep, and is emphasized by a relief margin at back. [...] The sides and back are rounded.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole to the lower edge of the spherical surface. One engraved day curve is visible always equidistant from the lower edge. The curve c from horizon to horizon is made up of the following arc length: 18, 19.2, 18.5, 16, 17.5, 16.5, 16.5, 17, 18.5, 19.5, 22, 21 mm. The lower edge of the dial face from the third to the ninth hour line is made up of the following arc lengths: 27.5, 27, 29, 27.5, 25, 27.5 mm.

generalInformation.note: Department: Greek & Roman Antiquities. Registration number: 1973, 0304.10.

generalInformation.description: A gnomon hole with lead is preserved in top surface of the dial above the meridian. This miniature dial is part of a funeral stele of the philosopher Theodotos, son of Menephron, dating from the second century B.C. [...] A tiny sphinx supports the shadow-receiving surface. A similar sphinx in the upper right corner probably also supported a sundial.

dialfaces.description: Ten hour lines are preserved, converging toward the gnomon groove. Only one engraved day curve crosses these hour lines. [...] The dial face is quarter sphere.

The shadow-receiving surface consists of two separate half quarter spheres joined to make a complete quarter sphere. The gnomon point is the corner of the solid juncture surface. Ten hour lines (five in each segment) stretch from the top center of the spherical surface to the lower edge. No day curves are visible.

generalInformation.note: Measurements and photograph from Ennaifer Mongi, Curator of the Carthage museum.

generalInformation.description: The shape of the two front parts´ transition follows the curve of the dialface. Two stylized legs flank the tall frontLP, until they seem to reimmerge in the base. Gibbs: A wedge-shaped hole at the back and a groove in the top surface once held the gnomon. [...] A framed area has been prepared, as if for inscription, on the base.

material.materialSubcategory: Gibbs: gray porous stone; Schaldach: marble
material.materialName: Gibbs: gray porous stone; Schaldach: marble

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend from the gnomon hole to a semicircle which has been engraved some distance from and not parallel to the lower edge of the dial. [...] The radius of the engraved circle is 88 mm. The curve c from the first hour line to the right horizon is made up of the following arc lengths: 21.5, 20, 20, 21, 19, 21, 21.5, 20 mm.

generalInformation.note: Schaldach: Schattenfläche nicht hohlkugelförmig, sondern zylindrisch

generalInformation.description: A rectangular gnomon hole is preserved in the front surface of the dial, along the meridian 20 mm from the top edge. Its dimensions are 27 mm long x 10 mm wide x 22 mm deep. [...] A wide lip emphasizes the circumference of the front section. The relief depicts a youthful figure playing a harp in a garden with various animals. Found in the ruins of ancient Dorostorum. The dial face is a flattened quarter sphere. Mladenova attributes the art work to the end of the second or the beginning of the third century A.D.

dialfaces.description: A crude grid of hour lines and day curves is combined with an elaborate relief design to form this dial. In all, thirteen hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole and continue to intersect the thin crescent formed by curves c_1 and c_2. Hour lines three and nine continue to intersect a second crescent formed by curves c_3 and c_4.

generalInformation.description: The present gnomon is not original, and museum restoration has destroyed any trace of the original gnomon hole. [...] The dial is dedicated to the Emperor Caracalla (Marcus Aurelius Severus Antonius) and his mother Julia Domna. Gatty says the dial was found at Aphrodisias before 1877.

material.materialName: white marble with streaks of gray

dialfaces.description: The eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across one engraved circle to a second. The day curves are parallel to each other but do not follow the curve of the lower edge. Marks in the dial surface above the two clearly visible day curves may form a third curve. (I have designated it c_1 in the measurements.) The dial is dedicated to the Emperor Caracalla (Marcus Aurelius Severus Antonius) and his mother Julia Domna. tc_2 subtends an angle of 39 at the center of the sphere tc_3 subtends an angle of 60 at the center of the sphere.
dialfaces.inscriptions: The spaces between hour lines are inscribed with large Greek letters:  Α Β Γ Δ Ε Σ Ζ Η Θ Ι ΙΑ ΙΒ.  The long Greek dedication on the base was inscribed with a different hand:   Αὐτοκρáτορι Καíθαρι Μ. Αὐρ(ηλιῳ) Σϵου’ηρῳ ‘Αντωϵíνῳ Σϵβ(αθτῳ) καì ‘Ιουλíᾳ  [Σ]ϵ [β] αθτῆ| μητρì [Κáστρων---------].

generalInformation.inscriptions: The spaces between hour lines are inscribed with large Greek letters:  Α Β Γ Δ Ε Σ Ζ Η Θ Ι ΙΑ ΙΒ.  The long Greek dedication on the base was inscribed with a different hand:   Αὐτοκρáτορι Καíθαρι Μ. Αὐρ(ηλιῳ) Σϵου’ηρῳ ‘Αντωϵíνῳ Σϵβ(αθτῳ) καì ‘Ιουλíᾳ  [Σ]ϵ [β] αθτῆ| μητρì [Κáστρων---------].

generalInformation.description: Traces of iron and lead remain in the gnomon hole. [...] Traces of bored holes in the eyes and mouth can be seen in the lion heads on four-toed paws which flank the base.

dialfaces.description: Of eleven hour lines, only the third, sixth and ninth continue beyond the summer solstice to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface. Three engraved day curves, always equidistant from each other, are visible. The day curves are not always equidistant from the oblique front edge. A chord from the top of the dial to the lowest point of the meridian has a sagitta of 10 mm at the equinox. The equinox curve is composed of arcs of the following lengths: 40.5, 58.5, 58, 51.5, 61.5, 59, 53, 55, 56, 54.5, 58, 62 mm. The  summer solstice curve is made up of arcs of the following lengths from the second to the tenth hour line: 73, 73, 77, 73, 72, 72, 72, 75 mm.

generalInformation.note: Department: Greek & Roman Antiquities. Registration number: 1821, 0301.1.

generalInformation.description: Two chunky short lion legs flank the concave frontLP ending in five-toed feet with claws. A flower with four petals and four diagonal small leaves sits between them. Gibbs: The gnomon hole is 28.5 mm deep.  [...]

dialfaces.description: The network of lines on this dial does not seem to be integrally related to the shape of the shadow-receiving surface.  The surface itself is a flattened segment of a sphere, oblique and horizontal sections being circles of radius from the gnomon hole to the lower edge of this surface. Three engraved day curves cross these hour lines. The day curves are equidistant from the lower edge of the flattened segment.

generalInformation.note: At one time in the Musée de Marseille.

generalInformation.description: The large base is decorated with four steps, as well as with panels outlined with a narrow molding. A four-petalled flower can be seen in the center of both left and right sides.

dialfaces.description: The corners and top left surface are damaged, but parts of eleven hour lines remain radiating from the gnomon hole to the lower edge of the spherical surface. Two day curves cross the hour lines.

Kommentar: \cite{MuseeAfricain} als Ref ohne Details im Bib file

dialfaces.description: The front parts of this sundial are connected by a torus moulding with two smaller horizontal mouldings on its top and bottom. The upper oblique part is decorated with two eight-leafed rosettes on either sides and a horizontal crescent in the middle. Gibbs:  A trace of lead fill is visible in the gnomon hole at the top center.

generalInformation.note: Found near Cherchel in 1901.

generalInformation.description: A trace remains of a rectangular gnomon hole in the top surface of the dial. TThe base of the dial is decorated with an uninscribed marble plaque. [...] The sides and back are rounded to follow the curve of the shadow-receiving surface. Found at Reka Devnia in the region of Trajan´s Marcianopolis.

dialfaces.description: A trace remains of a rectangular gnomon hole in the top surface of the dial. The curved receiving surface of this dial is neither conical nor spherical. The oblique front section appears to be circular: the horizontal section, elliptical. The meridian line is curved with sagitta at right. Nine hour lines extend between two engraved solstices and cross an equinox. All trace of hour lines ten and eleven is broken away at right. Only the meridian extends from the gnomon hole to the summer solstice. The base of the dial is decorated with an uninscribed marble plaque. The dial and base lean backward 4.8 from normal.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Found at Ostia in 1858.

dialfaces.description: A gnomon hole is preserved in the top surface of the dial above the meridian.  The rough-picked back of this dial is curved to follow the shape of the shadow-receiving surface. Eleven hour lines extend from the gnomon hole to the lower edge and are crossed by two parallel day curves.

generalInformation.description: The sundial´s surfaces are very eroded. It´s positioned on the forum in Volubilis (seen July 2014). There is no visible ornamentation.

dialfaces.description: The dial is badly damaged but appears to have a spherical shadow-receiving surface. Hour lines extend from top to bottom of dial face.

generalInformation.note: Measurements and descriptions from L. Janin.

generalInformation.description: A 26 mm deep cylindrical gnomon hole (diameter 20 mm) is connected by a groove 57.5 mm long to the front of the dial. [...] Found near the church of Josipdol; possibly from Cakovac or Metulum neat Ogulin. Presented to the museum in 1882.

dialfaces.description: The shadow receiving surface of this dial is a spherical cap. Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole to the lower edge. No engraved day curves are visible. Hour lines six to ten have the following lengths from gnomon to base: 528 mm, 517 mm, 487 mm, 420 mm,  314 mm. The arcs separating the hour lines along the base of the shadow-receiving surface from the second hour line to the eleventh hour line have the following lengths: 124, 124, 109, 115, 103.5, 111.5, 112.5, 155, 154 mm. The angles between hour lines from the first to the eleventh hour line are: 12, 21, 11.5, 12.5, 14, 12.5, 13, 13.5, 17, 20.
dialfaces.inscriptions: The Latin inscription includes letters  IO and M in the top corners and SOLINVINCT  C  NSER  AVGN below the dial face.

generalInformation.description: A vertical back, horizontal top and sloping front characterize the general shape of this dial. Two schematic feet flank its base. A rough-picked area divided by a vertical strip, and bounded by a semicircle, marks the location of the unfinished shadow-receiving surface. Found in the Agora of the Italians, Delos, Greece.

dialfaces.description: A vertical back, horizontal top and sloping front characterize the general shape of this dial.  Two schematic feet flank its base. A rough-picked area divided by a vertical strip, and bounded by a semicircle, marks the location of the unfinished shadow-receiving surface.

generalInformation.description: The surviving part is a portion of the right half of the sundial .

dialfaces.description: The surviving part is a portion of the right half of the sundial (see figure). The oblique front forms an angle of 33° with the rear vertical plane, very different from the latitude of Nepi, which is about 42°. The noon hour line is almost completely missing. The hour lines from VII to XI and parts of the winter solstice and equinox curves are present. The remaining segments of the day curves are of equal length: 22 mm on the winter solstice curve, 35 mm on the equinox, and 64 mm on the circular intersection with the oblique front cut.  Because of the few elements available it is difficult to make any reliable calculations or any evaluation of how accurate this sundial may have been.

generalInformation.note: Fragment, probably from the remains of Nepi, the ancient Etruscan town Nepete taken by the Romans in the fourth century B.C.

archive.holderInstitution: National Museum of Romanian History (Muzeul Național de Istorie a României)

generalInformation.description: The sundial is undamaged, except for chipped upper corners; and yet, no gnomon hole is preserved. Also there are no visible hour lines nor any visible day curves. The back is cylindrical.

dialfaces.description: The sundial is undamaged, except for chipped upper corners; and yet, no gnomon hole is preserved. Also there are no visible hour lines nor any visible day curves. The back is cylindrical.

Kommentar: DAi Foto: Forschungsarchiv für antike Plastik 627/4; 628/9 . Ergänzen: Römer in Rumänien, Ausstellungskatalog Köln (Köln 1969) 247 Kat.Nr. G 94 Taf. 32;

generalInformation.description: A hole at the junction of the summer solstice and the meridian, 11 mm x 10 mm and 18 mm deep, connects via a trough with the lower edge of the spherical surface. Also, there is evidence of a groove and a depression in the top surface of the monument above the meridian on the dial surface. A spherical depression in this large hexagonal monument has been marked for use as a sundial. Nine hour lines are preserved (3, 4, 5,6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and three engraved day curves are visible. None of the hour lines continue beyond either solstice.

dialfaces.description: A hole at the junction of the summer solstice and the meridian, 11 mm x 10 mm and 18 mm deep, connects via a trough with the lower edge of the spherical surface. Also, there is evidence of a groove and a depression in the top surface of the monument above the meridian on the dial surface. A spherical depression in this large hexagonal monument has been marked for use as a sundial. Nine hour lines are preserved (3, 4, 5,6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and three engraved day curves are visible. None of the hour lines continue beyond either solstice
dialfaces.inscriptions: A Nabatean inscription on the monument dates from the year 94 A.D.

generalInformation.inscriptions: A Nabatean inscription on the monument dates from the year 94 A.D.

generalInformation.description: There is no trace of a gnomon hole in the top edge. Reconstruction in the area of the bottom of the dial has obliterated any traces of a gnomon there. The hemispherical surface has been cut out of a cylindrical block. A square protrusion (for mounting?) 80 mm x 80 mm  remains in the center of the bottom surface. Dated from the artwork of a bronze figurine found nearby to the second century A.C.

dialfaces.description: The hemispherical surface has been cut out of a cylindrical block. A square protrusion (for mounting?) 80 mm x 80 mm  remains in the center of the bottom surface. The winter solstice seems to be punctuated with dots at the points where it is joined by the hour lines. Reconstruction makes determination of intended latitude difficult. Schlieben, who examined the unrestored pieces, finds \phi= 80 mm.
dialfaces.inscriptions: A Latin inscription on the lateral surface of the cylinder reads: -] NIVS * TA[- Schlieben completes the inscription as follows: LICINIVS TARENTINVS.

generalInformation.inscriptions: A Latin inscription on the lateral surface of the cylinder reads: -] NIVS * TA[- Schlieben completes the inscription as follows: LICINIVS TARENTINVS.

citations: \cite{Paulus1844}, p. 90 f, plates i and ii.
\cite{Schlieben1888}, p. 316 ff, and table 13, figures 7a and b.

generalInformation.description: In contrast to its richly engraved and inscribed dialface, the remains of this sundial’s corpus shows no additional adornment. The lower part is broken off and might have had a round shape, as is indicated by the bottom plane remains. Gibbs: There is no trace of a gnomon hole in the top edge of this dial. The rough surface at the front suggests that the face was once a complete hemisphere. If this was the case, then the gnomon could have been mounted in the bottom of the dial as S. Piale indicates, or in the top edge of the portion which is now broken away.

dialfaces.description: In addition to eleven hour lines and seven day curves (marking the entrance of the sun into each of the signs of the zodiac), a circle with vertical diameter coinciding with the meridian and equal to the distance between the solstices, and an isosceles triangle with axis also equal to the distance between the solstices and coinciding with the meridian, have been engraved on the shadow-receiving surface. The triangular figure represents the increase in daylight from winter solstice to summer solstice. $Arc c_1$ represents the path of the sun with declination 20.6 $Arc c_2$ represents the path of the sun with declination 11.30 $Arc c_3$ represents the path of the sun with declination -20.6 $Arc c_4$  represents the path of the sun with declination -11.30.
dialfaces.inscriptions: An inscription listing the month names of the signs of the zodiac, all in fine Greek characters, is distributed among the day curves in the order below:     ιανουριος   τοξ (óτησ)   αἰγ(óκϵρωσ)   ὁϵκϵμβριος //  φϵβραριος   ακó(ρπιοσ)   ὑὁρ(οκóοσ) νοϵμβριο[σ] //  [μ]αρτιος   ζυγ(óσ)   ἰκφ(úϵσ)   οκτωβρι[οσ] //  [απ)πιλιος   παρφ(éνοσ)   κρϵι(óσ)   σϵπτϵμβ[ριοσ] //  [μα]ιος   λéων   ταῦρ(οσ)   αυγο[νστοσ] //  [ιουν]ιος   καρκí(νοσ)   ὁíὁυμ(οι)  ι[ουλιοσ]

generalInformation.inscriptions: An inscription listing the month names of the signs of the zodiac, all in fine Greek characters, is distributed among the day curves in the order below:     ιανουριος   τοξ (óτησ)   αἰγ(óκϵρωσ)   ὁϵκϵμβριος //  φϵβραριος   ακó(ρπιοσ)   ὑὁρ(οκóοσ) νοϵμβριο[σ] //  [μ]αρτιος   ζυγ(óσ)   ἰκφ(úϵσ)   οκτωβρι[οσ] //  [απ)πιλιος   παρφ(éνοσ)   κρϵι(óσ)   σϵπτϵμβ[ριοσ] //  [μα]ιος   λéων   ταῦρ(οσ)   αυγο[νστοσ] //  [ιουν]ιος   καρκí(νοσ)   ὁíὁυμ(οι)  ι[ουλιοσ]
generalInformation.note: Found in the Via Palombara on the Esquiline in 1805.

generalInformation.description: A single hemisphere without central gnomon point, once had two separate gnomon points corresponding to the north and south facing halves of the dial face. The gnomon points were placed in the meridian plane so that the summer solstice of the south-facing surface virtually coincided with the winter solstice of the north-facing surface. Grids have been engraved on both the north and south facing halves of the hemispherical shadow-receiving surface of this dial. Since gnomon holes near the top edge may be associated with each dial grid, the hole in the bottom center of the hemisphere presumably served to drain off accumulated water.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines extend from the winter solstice across the equinox to the summer solstice. The meridian continues to the top edge. For $\epsilon = 24$, a graphic determination of the gnomon length gives $g = 92.4 mm$. Arc lengths along summer solstice from the sixth to the eleventh hour lines measure 40, 43.5, 43.5, 40, 49 mm.

A spike gnomon 47 mm long is fixed along the meridian 23.5 mm from the top edge. Eleven hour lines extend from the summer solstice across the equinox to the winter solstice. The meridian continues to the top edge. For $\epsilon = 24$, a graphic determination of the gnomon length gives $g = 21 mm$. Arc lengths along summer solstice from the sixth to the eleventh hour lines measure: 38, 36, 37, 24.8, 22.1 mm. Arc lengths along the winter solstice from the sixth to the twelfth hour lines measure: 62.2, 40.3, 47, 42, 47, 39 mm.

generalInformation.note: diameter of hemisphere 323, diameter of drain hole 13

generalInformation.description: Only the left half of this dial is preserved. However, broken edges suggest that the shadow-receiving surface was once a complete hemisphere. Six finely engraved hour lines and three day curves are visible. The hour lines do not extend beyond the solstice curves.

dialfaces.description: Only the left half of this dial is preserved. However, broken edges suggest that the shadow-receiving surface was once a complete hemisphere. Six finely engraved hour lines and three day curves are visible. The hour lines do not extend beyond the solstice curves.

generalInformation.description: No ornaments are visible on the remaining upper corpus of this sundial. Gibbs: There is no trace of a gnomon hole in the smooth surface at the top or the broken surface at the lower front. The broken edge at the front of this dial suggests that the dial face was once a complete hemisphere.

dialfaces.description: The broken edge at the front of this dial suggests that the dial face was once a complete hemisphere. Now traces of eleven hour lines remain on worn shadow-receiving surface. Where the surface is not as badly worn hour lines can be seen to extend beyond the lowest day curve to the broken edge. In all, four day curves are preserved. An engraved line in the top surface marks the meridian position. The diameter of the spherical hollow is approximately 200 mm. C_1 corresponds to $ \sigma = 24.48$ C_2 corresponds to $\sigma = 22.12$ C_3 corresponds to  \sigma = 14.30.

generalInformation.description: A probable gnomon hole can be seen in the top surface of the dial. It is cylindrical, 22 mm in diameter, and 44 mm deep. The transposed halves of a hemisphere from the shadow-receiving surface of this dial. On each side five hour lines stretch between the two solstices and across the equinox. The meridian line is not engraved on either side. An engraved line connects the equinoxes across the top of the dial. On the west facing side, the summer solstice continues from the hollow onto the plane surface. On the east facing side, an engraved line cuts the plane meridian edge a little south of the summer solstice. Greek inscriptions mark the day curves. The prow of a ship, pierced by a small hole, decorates the south side of the block.

dialfaces.description: The transposed halves of a hemisphere from the shadow-receiving surface of this dial. On each side five hour lines stretch between the two solstices and across the equinox. The meridian line is not engraved on either side. An engraved line connects the equinoxes across the top of the dial. On the west facing side, the summer solstice continues from the hollow onto the plane surface. On the east facing side, an engraved line cuts the plane meridian edge a little south of the summer solstice. Greek inscriptions mark the day curves.

generalInformation.description: The sketch published in Inscriptiones Graecae was drawn from photographs. The equinox, the summer solstice line and a line near the summer solstice are marked with Greek inscription. The dial is composed of transposed quarter spheres each engraved with five hour lines and four day curves. Found along a street on the island of Kea.

dialfaces.description: The equinox, the summer solstice line and a line neat the summer solstice are marked with Greek inscription. The dial is composed of transposed quarter spheres each engraved with five hour lines and four day curves.
