A photograph captioned Sundials at Pompeii published in Gabba, L., and Jacono, l. Meridiana, Enciclopedia Italiana, p. 903, shows a complete conical sundial which cannot be identified with other catalogue entries.

generalInformation.description: A lead-filled gnomon hole is visible in the top surface of the dial. Of the eleven hour lines, only the meridian extends from the gnomon groove to the lower edge of the conical surface; although some other hour lines do seem to extend beyond the summer solstice. In addition to the summer solstice, both the equinox and the winter solstice are represented by engraved lines. Sprouting calyx, flower and curling tendril are carved in low relief on the sides of the dial. Two lion feet flank a base inscribed with an Oscan inscription.

dialfaces.description: A lead-filled gnomon hole is visible in the top surface of the dial. Of the eleven hour lines, only the meridian extends from the gnomon groove to the lower edge of the conical surface; although some other hour lines do seem to extend beyond the summer solstice. In addition to the summer solstice, both the equinox and the winter solstice are represented by engraved lines.

site.siteSpecific: House of the Figured Capitals, Reg. VII, Ins.4

dialfaces.description: Lead fill remains in the gnomon hole at the top of the dial. Three day curves are divided unevenly by eleven hour lines. A simple engraved design decorates the oblique front surface. Below the design, a rolled scroll molding fills the angle between the simple base and the oblique front.

generalInformation.description: The base of a bronze gnomon remains in lead fill at the top of the dial. Eleven hour lines extend from the gnomon groove to the lower edge of the conical surface. Three day curves cross these hour lines. A 52 mm wide lip emphasizes the circular section in the oblique front of the dial. Two four-toed lion feet flank the base. The left and right sides meet at the back of the dial forming a dihedral angle equal to 88.

dialfaces.description: The base of a bronze gnomon remains in lead fill at the top of the dial. Eleven hour lines extend from the gnomon groove to the lower edge of the conical surface. Three day curves cross these hour lines. A 52 mm wide lip emphasizes the circular section in the oblique front of the dial. Two four-toed lion feet flank the base. The left and right sides meet at the back of the dial forming a dihedral angle equal to 88.  The meridian line is not properly graduated for either a south or a north-facing cone with gnomon point on the axis of the conical surface.

generalInformation.note: The meridian line is not properly graduated for either a south or a north-facing cone with gnomon point on the axis of the conical surface.

generalInformation.description: The gnomon in position is restoration. The area above the winter solstice has been chipped away to from a two inch indentation. Eleven hour lines extend from the winter solstice across the equinox to the summer solstice. Two legs flank a stepped base.

dialfaces.description: The gnomon in position is restoration. The area above the winter solstice has been chipped away to from a two inch indentation. Eleven hour lines extend from the winter solstice across the equinox to the summer solstice. Two legs flank a stepped base.

generalInformation.description: Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across the equinox to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across the equinox to the lower edge of the shadow-receiving surface.

generalInformation.note: The drawing is not adequate to the dial. The dial has no base as it is shown in the drawing.

generalInformation.description: The thirteen engraved hour lines include two neat the horizontal top edge. The fourth, seventh, and tenth hour lines are specially marked. Three engraved day curves are visible. The oblique front is decorated with a simple geometric design which includes a crescent.

dialfaces.description: The thirteen engraved hour lines include two neat the horizontal top edge. The fourth, seventh, and tenth hour lines are specially marked. Three engraved day curves are visible.

generalInformation.note: Found in the Via Appia near the Circus of Caracalla in Rome. The dial was seen in the Archiginnasio della Sapienza in Rome in 1816.

generalInformation.description: The preserved hour lines (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8) continue beyond the winter solstice toward the gnomon hole and also continue beyond the summer solstice onto the lip border. The two engraved solstices and equinox are parallel to each other. A depressed margin, stepped molding, and two narrow half columns decorate the base.

dialfaces.description: The preserved hour lines (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8) continue beyond the winter solstice toward the gnomon hole and also continue beyond the summer solstice onto the lip border. The two engraved solstices and equinox are parallel to each other.

generalInformation.description: The much worn surface of this dial still shows eleven scratched hour lines. In taking the above measurements I have assumed certain vague traces to be the winter solstice and the equinox. Any trace of summer solstice has broken away.

dialfaces.description: The much worn surface of this dial still shows eleven scratched hour lines. In taking the above measurements I have assumed certain vague traces to be the winter solstice and the equinox. Any trace of summer solstice has broken away.

generalInformation.description: A small round hole in the top surface of the dial probably held part of the gnomon. Seven deeply engraved hour lines (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7) are preserved in the badly damaged shadow-receiving surface. Parts of the parallel solstices and equinox remain. Two lion feet support the dial on the left and right sides of the base. The foot motif is carried around to similar reliefs on the left and right sides of the dial which also include a design which incorporates stalks [tendrils] springing from calyxes.

dialfaces.description: A small round hole in the top surface of the dial probably held part of the gnomon.   Seven deeply engraved hour lines (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7) are preserved in the badly damaged shadow-receiving surface. Parts of the parallel solstices and equinox remain.

generalInformation.description: The museum has restored this dial by joining two halves. Eleven hour lines cross three day curves. The third, sixth, and ninth hour lines are specially marked. A simple sloping base supports the dial face.

dialfaces.description: The museum has restored this dial by joining two halves. Eleven hour lines cross three day curves.  The third, sixth, and ninth hour lines are specially marked.
dialfaces.inscriptions: The third, sixth, and ninth hour lines are specially marked.

generalInformation.note: Found in the ruins of ancient in the Pio Clementine museum (modern Otricoli) and placed in the Pio Clementine museum in 1787.

generalInformation.description: This dial fragment appears to be conical. Parts of six hour lines (4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9) and two day curves (equinox and summer solstice) are preserved.

dialfaces.description: This dial fragment appears to be conical. Parts of six hour lines (4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9) and two day curves (equinox and summer solstice) are preserved.

generalInformation.description: The gnomon groove above the meridian still contains the lead fill. Thirteen hour lines have been scratched deeply into the shadow-receiving surface from the gnomon to the lower edge. Only the lightest trace of winter solstice and equinox remain. The base exhibits a cyma profile.

dialfaces.description: The gnomon groove above the meridian still contains the lead fill. Thirteen hour lines have been scratched deeply into the shadow-receiving surface from the gnomon to the lower edge. Only the lightest trace of winter solstice and equinox remain. The base exhibits a cyma profile.

generalInformation.note: Found in the necropolis of Altino.

generalInformation.description: A gnomon hole is preserved in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. The first and second of eleven hour lines are broken away on this beautifully made dial. The two solstices limit the length of the remaining hour lines. Both solstices are parallel to the equinox and the lower edge. A half-cylinder molding decorates the base.

dialfaces.description: A gnomon hole is preserved in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. The first and second of eleven hour lines are broken away on this beautifully made dial. The two solstices limit the length of the remaining hour lines. Both solstices are parallel to the equinox and the lower edge.

generalInformation.description: Eleven hour lines appear, at least at the equinox, to have been engraved after the three day curves. Only the meridian continues beyond the winter solstice to the gnomon hole. A simple engraved geometric design decorates the oblique front surface. Two four-toed lion feet flank the base.

dialfaces.description: Eleven hour lines appear, at least at the equinox, to have been engraved after the three day curves. Only the meridian continues beyond the winter solstice to the gnomon hole.

generalInformation.description: The gnomon hole has a semicircular vertical section 50 mm wide and 51 mm deep. Eleven hour lines extend from winter to summer solstice. The three day curves have been engraved always equidistant from each other and from the lower edge of the conical surface. Dots are visible at the junctions of hour lines and winter solstice.

dialfaces.description: The gnomon hole has a semicircular vertical section 50 mm wide and 51 mm deep. Eleven hour lines extend from winter to summer solstice. The three day curves have been engraved always equidistant from each other and from the lower edge of the conical surface. Dots are visible at the junctions of hour lines and winter solstice.

generalInformation.description: Part of a gnomon hole is visible in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. Only the right half of the dial surface is preserved. Five hour lines (7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and parts of three day curves are visible in the photograph.

generalInformation.description: Twelve hour lines are visible in Delamare´s drawing; also, two day curves can be seen. Front sides are heavily decorated with scrolls, acanthus, and ivy. A gnomon hole is visible in the top surface.

generalInformation.description: Kroeper: Two faces of the stone are worked, one has a plane angled surface, the opposite side a conoidal face. Both sides have 12 radial lightly engraved lines on their respective surfaces emanating from the top edge of the stone downward. At the top of the stone is a hole in which originally the shadow throwing, probably, metal rod was placed. Of particular interest in this example are the two faces (PI. V, fig. 1), one for normal use oriented with the face to the south, the other for use near the summer solstice (oriented north).  blogspot.com: The hour marks are set on two opposing sides of this sandstone block. The top side has a cavity for the gnomon.

dialfaces.description: Concave side The hour marks are set on two opposing sides of this sandstone block. The top side has a cavity for the gnomon.

The hour marks are set on two opposing sides of this sandstone block. The top side has a cavity for the gnomon.  Catamo: The Naqca dial is of the conical type, with its vertex elevated (Gibbs §2a) only about 10 mm above the top surface, so that it closely resembles the rare type (§2c) in which this elevation would be zero. But this resemblance refers to the abstract geometrical properties only, not to the general aspect, which is quite different from the single case described by Gibbs, due to the considerable difference in latitude. Since in the case of Gibbs's §2c the hour lines are exact straight lines of equal length, they here deviate only slightly from such a geometrical layout: all eleven are 275±6 mm long and deviate no more than 9 mm from their full length chords in any place except one, namely that of the first morning hour. Day lines are lacking. The southern front plane is inclined by 18±2° to the vertical, with the uncertainty being due to some unevenness but still allowing agreement with the 16° of the local latitude. A unique feature occurs in that the northern front plane of the whole block is parallel to it and therefore parallel to the equatorial plane as well, so that it receives sunlight at any hour during exactly the entire summer half-year, a fact which allows it to be equipped with a second gnomon that projects its shadow onto it during the six summer months. Eleven radial hour lines are present accordingly. The two described inclined planes give the red sandstone block (apart from its base, which protrudes southward) the shape of a rhombohedron with all its twelve edges of roughly 450 mm in length.

generalInformation.description: Because of erosion the coastline has retreated some 80 metres, with the result that the tower is now surrounded by the sea and the ruins of the villa have been completely submerged. Recently a causeway was built to connect the tower to the land, and this has completely buried the ruins of the villa. On the beach, in the years prior to 1980, the writer found innumerable shapeless fragments of ornamental Roman stones - marble, porphyry, granite - and amongst these was somewhat less than half of a white marble conical sundial, considerably rounded because of the action of the waves. The fragment is now in the co-author's possession (and at the disposal of the relevant Archaeological Superintendence).

dialfaces.description: It was possible to measure the angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is about 42°, consistent with that of Torre Flavia. In spite of its poor state, three hour lines and two winter solstice and equinox arcs are still visible (see figure).

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Eleven hour lines divide two day curves and the lower edge.   Healey: The dial is made of soft local sandstone and it has been quite badly abraded. It is not clear from Janssen and Savignao whether it was in better condition when found, though their drawing is certainly idealized! In design it is a typical Roman Hellenistic dial. The time-keeping surface is a quarter-sphere, 12.65 cm in radius, divided by eleven lines (intended to be equidistant from each other, though in reality they are a little irregular) marking the hours of the day. The gnomon was set horizontally, though it is not likely that the present gnomon is the original one, since Janssen and Savignao imply that the gnomon was missing. The dial was designed to face south and the south-facing face is vertical (though ancient dials of this type are often undercut). In addition to the hour-lines there is a single day-curve parallel to the front edge and 5 cm. from it, marking a particular day in the solar year. On dials of this kind it is more usual to find three day-curves, one for each solstice and one for the equinox. Where only one line appears it is normally the equinox line.

generalInformation.description: At the top left corner of the dial, above the left meridian, there is a gnomon hole containing some trace of lead fill. The shadow-receiving surface of this dial is essentially that of a section of truncated cone which has been split at the meridian and transposed before being cut into the stone. Rather than continuing smoothly to the top of the dial, the conical surface is cut off above the winter solstice by a rough protrusion on each side. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are crossed by three day curves within each dial half. The summer solstice is distinct from the lower edge, but the winter curve is marked only by the junction of the smooth conical surface with the rough protrusion. The center front surface of the dial has been decorated with a relief showing a priestly figure wearing a polos and a flowing robe, reaching for the tendrils of a symmetrically framing plant.

generalInformation.note: Found in 1968 in the ruins of a Paleochristian basilica on Rhodes.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Two square holes diametrically opposite from each other in the hexagonally shaped top surface of the dial are probably gnomon holes. Gnomons placed in these holes could have served all four shadow-receiving surfaces. The central rectangular hole (132 mm long, 20 mm wide, and 56.5 mm deep) and associated grooves still contain a trace of lead and may have been part of the gnomon system. More probably they held some ornament or additional timekeeping device. The dial is supported by a ship-shaped base decorated on the left and right sides by reliefs depicting bearded giants whose tails end in acanthus leaves. Four separate line grids have been engraved on the transposed halves of the north and south facing conical surfaces. Schaldach: Die beiden Schattenflächen I und II befinden sich auf der Bug-Seite. Die Uhr I zeigt die Nachmittagsstunden, die östliche Uhr II die Vormittagsstunden an. Das Heck unter der N-Seite ist abgebrochen. Die beiden südlichen Schattenflächen sind vorkragend, ihre für die Größe dieser Uhr zu breiten Stundenlinien gehen über die Sommerwendlinien hinaus. Die weggebrochenen äußeren Kanten bildeten jeweils die Mittagslinie. Die Winterwendlinie von I ist nur teilweise erhalten. Auch die beiden Schattenflächen III und IV auf der Nordseite sind symmetrisch angeordnet. Die konkave Höhlung ist hier allerdings nur schwach ausgeprägt und die Linien sind kaum mehr zu erkennen. In der Deckfläche befinden sich an den Stellen A und E die Gnomonlöcher. Sie hielten die Gnomone, welche jeweils zwei Schattenflächen bedienten. Die Löcher B und D sind nur flach und haben vielleicht das Wegrutschen beweglicher Stangen verhindert. Im länglichen Loch C (Weite: 135 mm x 20 mm, Tiefe: 55 mm) befanden sich Reste von einem flexiblen, rötlichen Material (Leder?). Ich vermute mit Basch, dass die Löcher B, C und D eine Art Segel hielten, um das Schiff zu vervollständigen.

dialfaces.description: Surface 1. Hour lines on this face extend from the engraved winter solstice across the engraved equinox and summer solstice to the lower edge. The meridian is not engraved on either surface, but ten other hour lines are preserved.

Surfaces 3. Measurements were taken from the better preserved west side segment. On it, five hour lines (7, 8, 9, 10, 11), winter solstice and equinox are scratched. The seemingly poor engraving job may only be the effect of weathering. The meridian probably coincides with the west edge. It is possibly that the lower edge marked the summer solstice. Measurements taken on the east side confirm those on the west.

Surface 2. Hour lines on this face extend from the engraved winter solstice across the engraved equinox and summer solstice to the lower edge. The meridian is not engraved on either surface, but ten other hour lines are preserved.

Surfaces 4. Measurements were taken from the better preserved west side segment. On it, five hour lines (7, 8, 9, 10, 11), winter solstice and equinox are scratched. The seemingly poor engraving job may only be the effect of weathering. The meridian probably coincides with the west edge. It is possibly that the lower edge marked the summer solstice. Measurements taken on the east side confirm those on the west.

generalInformation.note: A dial with a similar ship base, but without reliefs was found in the gymnasium on Delos (see 1072G) Basch observes that the ship is characteristic of those of the Hellenistic period. The Triton figure dates from the second century A.D., possibly copying a Hellenistic design.

generalInformation.description: The gnomon hole at the left side is 8 mm in diameter. It slants downward at an angle 45 from the horizontal. The right gnomon hole is lead filled. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. The base is a schematic lion´s paw.

dialfaces.description: The gnomon hole at the left side is 8 mm. It slants downward at an angle 45 from the horizontal. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. Only the meridian continues above the winter solstice to the gnomon hole. Four day curves, engraved always equidistant from each other and from the lower edge of the dial surface, are visible.

The right gnomon hole is lead filled. The transposed halves of a dished conical surface form the shadow-receiving area of this dial. The sagitta at the left equinox is about  8 mm; at right, 9 mm. Six hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on each side. Only the meridian continues above the winter solstice to the gnomon hole. Four day curves, engraved always equidistant from each other and from the lower edge of the dial surface, are visible.

generalInformation.note: The dial has been characterized as an Egyptian work of Imperial date.

generalInformation.description: The unique shape of this dial face is shown in the adjoining meridian section. The surface is conical, possibly a complete right circular cone. The vertex of the conical surface is carved out of the stone. Its position is marked by a shallow, square, depression which contains no metal. The generator of the conical surface is horizontal at the meridian. Seven preserved hour lines, containing traces of black coloring, cross three day curves, but do not extend beyond either solstice. The day curves do not seem to be parallel to each other, and certainly the summer solstice is not always equidistant from the lower edge.

generalInformation.description: Die rechte Hälfte des Uhrenkörpers fehlt. Die Linien sind relativ breit und tief. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht vorhanden. Die Stundenlinien enden an einem gerundeten, stark vorkragenden Limbus, wie er bei Sonnenuhren der rhodischen Form vorkommt. Auf der linken Seite ist der Ansatz eines Fußes erkennbar. Im Uhrenkörper unterhalb der abgebrochenen Deckfläche liegen zwei  7 mm breite Befestigungslöcher, welche wohl für den Gnomon bestimmt waren.

dialfaces.description: Die rechte Hälfte des Uhrenkörpers fehlt. 5 Stundenlinien (7 bis 11) und zwei Datumslinien. Die Linien sind relativ breit und tief. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht vorhanden. Die Stundenlinien enden an einem gerundeten, stark vorkragenden Limbus, wie er bei Sonnenuhren der rhodischen Form vorkommt. Auf der linken Seite ist der Ansatz eines Fußes erkennbar. Im Uhrenkörper unterhalb der abgebrochenen Deckfläche liegen zwei  7 mm breite Befestigungslöcher, welche wohl für den Gnomon bestimmt waren.

generalInformation.note: Found in October 1989, north of Hadrian´s library.

generalInformation.description: Die Schattenfläche ist entweder kegelförmig oder zylindrisch. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht eingemeißelt. Da außerdem ein großer Teil der Schattenfläche fehlt, ist nicht zu erkennen, ob andere Datumslinien vorhanden waren. Die Stundenlinien enden noch vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche und halten dort einen Abstand von etwa 35 mm voneinander. Seitenflächen und Rückwand sind geebnet.

dialfaces.description: Die Schattenfläche ist entweder kegelförmig oder zylindrisch. 3 Stundenlinien, keine Datumslinie. Eine Sommerwendlinie ist nicht eingemeißelt. Da außerdem dein großer Teil der Schattenfläche fehlt, ist nicht zu erkennen, ob andere Datumslinien vorhanden waren. Die Stundenlinien enden noch vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche und halten dort einen Abstand von etwa 35 mm voneinander.

generalInformation.note: Kegelförmig oder zylindrisch; Fund vom September 1999; Nordflügel Hadriansbibliothek, dort als Spolie in Mauer.

generalInformation.description: 11 Stundenlinien und zwei Datumslinien. Die Stundenlinien der kleinen Uhr sind gleichmäßig vertieft, die Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die Winterwendlinie wurde als Kreis um den Gnomonfußpunkt gezeichnet, weshalb sie nicht parallel zur Äquinoktiallinie liegt. Dadurch vergrößert sich ihr Abstand voneinander zu den Randstunden hin. Die beiden Randstunden sind breiter als die übrigen Stunden. Auch ist dort die Krümmung der Schattenfläche nicht mehr konisch. In der Deckfläche befinden sich zwei Gnomonlöcher, das eine ist nach vorne hin ausgebrochen, in dem anderen sind Spuren von Blei. Die Vorderfläche ist eben. Zwischen den dreizehigen Löwentatzen ist ein flacher Limbus von 2 cm Breite.

generalInformation.note: Fund von P. Themelis im Juni 1979; in einem spätrömischen Bad des antiken Kallipolis (heute ein Stausee)

generalInformation.description: 11 Stundenlinien und drei Datumslinien. Die Schattenfläche der Uhr, die aus drei Bruchstücken wieder zusammengefügt ist, weitet sich zum Betrachter hin wie eine Kegelsonnenuhr und zur Deckfläche hin wie eine Hohlkugelsonnenuhr. Die Vorderfläche steht fast senkrecht, so dass sich das Bild einer Viertelkugel ergibt. Die Achse der Datumlinien ist horizontal ausgerichtet. Alle Linien sind sehr grob gezogen. Die Segmente für die Morgen- und Abendstunden sind breiter als bei den anderen Stunden. Die Pseudodatumslinie, die etwa 1 cm Abstand vom unteren Rand der Schattenfläche hält, ist nicht vollständig erhalten. In der Deckfläche verläuft eine 25 mm lange Rinne für einen metallenen Gnomon, dessen Befestigungsloch sich auf der geebneten Rückseite befindet. Auf der Basis umgrenzen Füße zwei voneinander abgeteilte Felder, die beschriftet sind.

dialfaces.inscriptions: Das obere Feld enthält einen Eigennamen: T[itus] Granius Felix Locher gibt nur den Inhalt des obersten Feldes Kotsias liest hier Feti[us]. Im unteren Feld heißt es: Aed[ilis]. Lib[ero]. Patzri et thiaso d[e] s[uis] f[aciendum] c[uravit].

generalInformation.inscriptions: Δας οβϵρϵ Φϵλδ ϵντηäλτ ϵινϵν Ειγϵνναμϵν: Τ[ιτυσ] Γρανιυς Φϵλιξ Λοϛηϵρ γιβτ νυρ δϵν Ινηαλτ δϵς οβϵρστϵν Φϵλδϵς Κοτσιας λιϵστ ηιϵρ Φϵτι[υσ]. Ιμ υντϵρϵν Φϵλδ ηϵιßτ ϵσ: Αϵδ[ιλισ]. Λιβ[ϵρο]. Πατζρι ϵτ τηιασο δ[ϵ] σ[υισ] φ[αϛιϵνδυμ] ϛ[υραvιτ].
generalInformation.note: Fundort: Dionysos-Heiligtum, Dion, in der Nähe des hellenistischen Theaters

generalInformation.description: 11 feine Stundenlinien und drei Datumslinien. Geringe Teile der Deckfläche von der Schattenfläche sind abgebrochen. Der gerundete Gnomonkanal ist 9 mm tief, 14 mm breit und 32 mm lang. Rötliche Spuren einer Oxydation verlaufen ausgehend von der Halterung über die Schattenfläche. Die Basis ist schmucklos, wölbt sich konvex im oberen Teil und geht dann lotrecht nach unten.

generalInformation.note: Fundort: Zeus-Heiligtum in Petres.

generalInformation.description: Die Stundenlinien (4 bis 11, keine Datumslinie) verlaufen in einem exakten Abstand voneinander und sind gleichmäßig vertieft. 16 mm vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche kreuzt ein kurzer Strich die Mittagslinie. Die Abstände der Stundenlinien auf Höhe des Querstrichs betragen jeweils 34 mm. Die Neigung der Vorderfläche passt zu Thessaloniki. Der Limbus hat eine Breite von 16 mm. Zwei naturgetreu gearbeitete Löwenfüße zeichnen den Fund aus.

dialfaces.description: Die Stundenlinien (4 bis 11, keine Datumslinie) verlaufen in einem exakten Abstand voneinander und sind gleichmäßig vertieft. 16 mm vor dem unteren Rand der Schattenfläche kreuzt ein kurzer Strich die Mittagslinie. generalInformation.description: Die Stundenlinien (11, zwei Datumslinien) sind gleichmäßig vertieft, aber nur ungenau ausgearbeitet. Die Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Locher führte ihr Fehlen darauf zurück, dass der vordere Teil der Schattenfläche abgebrochen sei. Das ist nicht nachzuvollziehen: nur die Enden sind abgebrochen. Ein Limbus von 22-25 mm Breite umgrenzt die Schattenfläche. In der Deckfläche ist eine v-förmige Vertiefung für einen schmalen metallenen Gnomon, auf der nur grob gearbeiteten Rückwand ist ein Befestigungsloch zu erkennen. Die Basis ist abgebrochen.

generalInformation.description: 6 Stundenlinien (3 bis 8) und zwei Datumslinien. Die Sommerwendlinie fehlt.  Die Uhr ist aus zwei Bruchstücken wieder zusammengesetzt. Auf der Schattenfläche ist in schwarzer Farbe eine alte Inventarnummer (E377) aufgemalt. Die rückseitig gerundete Uhr ruht auf einer vierzehigen, etwa 100 mm hohen Löwentatze.

dialfaces.description: 6 Stundenlinien (3 bis 8) und zwei Datumslinien. Die Sommerwendlinie fehlt.  Die Uhr ist aus zwei Bruchstücken wieder zusammengesetzt.

generalInformation.description: 9 Stundenlinien (2 bis 10, keine Datumslinie) wurden in eine Viertel-Hohlkugel (Radius 95-105 mm) grob eingemeißelt. Die Randsektoren sind etwas breiter und stehen offenbar für je zwei Morgen- und Abendstunden, was eine 10-teilige Schattenfläche ergibt. Die Stundenlinien haben einen unregelmäßigen Abstand voneinander und verlaufen vom Fußpunkt des Gnomons zum unteren Rand der Schattenfläche. Eine 35 mm lange und sehr flache, zweigeteilte Gnomonrinne halbiert die Deckfläche. Basis und Befestigungslöcher fehlen.

dialfaces.description: 9 Stundenlinien (2 bis 10, keine Datumslinie) wurden in eine Viertel-Hohlkugel (Radius 95-105 mm) grob eingemeißelt. generalInformation.note: Fundort: Bruchsteindepot nahe des Palaimon-Tempels.

generalInformation.description: Die Uhr hat 11 Stundenlinien und zwei Datumslinien. Die Schattenfläche ist nur schwach gewölbt. Sie weist Verletzungen durch eine Baggerschaufel auf sowie das Fehlen größere Teile auf der linken Seite. Die Stundenlinien sind relativ breit (2 mm) und scharf gezogen. Eine Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die beiden vorhandenen Datumslinien neigen sich nach innen (Pseudodatumslinien). In der Deckfläche befindet sich ein Gnomonloch (Weite 300 mm x 30 mm, Tiefe 20 mm) und eine schmale Gnomonrinne. An den beiden Seitenflächen der Basis sieht man zwei Fischreliefs (eintauchende Delphine?) über einer 25 mm hohen Bodenplatte. Zwischen den Fischköpfen auf der Vorderseite liegt ein freies, etwa 155 mm x 60 mm großes Feld. Die Bodenfläche ist ohne Dübelloch.

dialfaces.description: Die Uhr hat 11 Stundenlinien und zwei Datumslinien. Die Schattenfläche ist nur schwach gewölbt. Die beiden vorhandenen Datumslinien neigen sich nach innen (Pseudodatumslinien). In der Deckfläche befindet sich  ein Gnomonloch (Weite 300 mm x 30 mm, Tiefe 20 mm) und eine schmale Gnomonrinne.

generalInformation.description: 10 Stundenlinien (1 bis 10) und zwei Datumslinien, relativ breit (bis 2 mm). Die Schattenfläche ist für die Abendstunden ganz abgebrochen. Die zehnte Stundenlinie ist nur noch ansatzweise erkennbar. Eine Sommerwendlinie fehlt. Die Mittagslinie geht als einzige Stundenlinie über die Winterwendlinie hinaus bis zum Gnomonloch. Bleireste (25 mm x 25 mm) bedecken das Gnomonloch, das für einen schmalen, flachen Gnomon gearbeitet war. Ein etwa 20 mm breiter, im Mittelteil allerdings nicht durchgehender Limbus trennt die Schattenfläche von der Basis. Die Reste eines Reliefs schließen sich an, das einen Fischschwarm darstellt. Die Rückwand ist gerundet. Die Basis ist abgebrochen.

generalInformation.description: Traces of iron gnomon remain in gnomon hole 13 mm in diameter. Meridian and equinox line divide the shadow-receiving surface into four equal rectangles. The usual eleven hour line/three day curve grid has been modified to include two straight lines which radiate from the point of intersection of meridian and winter solstice at angles of 25 (left) and 24 (right).

generalInformation.note: Found in a house during the excavation of Couve in 1894.

generalInformation.description: The iron gnomon, now broken off at the base, is held in place by a lead adhesive. A permanent glass covering makes modern measurement impossible. The figures at left were obtained from Grablovitz´ early publication and recent photographs. These researched and calculated results compare favorably with measurements taken from a plaster cast of the dial displayed in the Museo della Civitá romana.  The windrose surrounding the dial is inscribed in Latin Both inscriptions, the eleven hour lines and three day curves are emphasized by a black coloring which may not be original.

generalInformation.note: The dial was found in 1878 near the ruins of a small Jupiter temple in the northwestern part of the Roman city of Aquileia. Kenner dates the epigraphy to the republic or early empire.

generalInformation.description: Traces of three hour lines, equinox, and one solstice remain on this dial fragment. It is possible that the bottom edge follows the curve of the other solstice. A red 392 has been painted on the back of the dial.

generalInformation.description: The base of a bronze gnomon, 12 mm wide, remains in a lead-filled hole. Two round holes at the left side of the dial block may have served for mounting. Meridian and equinox divide the shadow-receiving surface into four rectangles. The grid of eleven hour lines and three day curves may have been determind by the dots which mark the junctions of hour lines and solstices.

generalInformation.description: The core of the gnomon hole, containing no metal, is visible in the center of a large circular scarred area along the meridian above the summer solstice. This dial has been carved on the horizontal section of a column 43 cm in diameter. The grid of lines includes eleven hour lines and three day curves. The points of intersection of hour lines and solstices are marked by dots. The meridian extends beyond winter and summer solstices to the edges of the section.

generalInformation.note: Found at Pompeii in 1865 and deposited in the museum in Naples. Gibbs was unable to locate it in the spring of 1971. The dial appears to consist of eleven hour lines, including an extended inscribed meridian, and seven inscribed day curves.

citations: \cite{Fiorelli1865}, p. 14 ff with drawing (IG, XIV, 705 with drawing).

archivalInformation.dating: period of Antonius Pius, about 138 CE

generalInformation.description: A trace of gnomon hole is preserved along the broken right edge which coincides with the meridian of the dial. No metal remains. Three fragments have been joined to form the left half of a sundial. The equinox crosses and extends a little beyond the six preserved hour lines. Winter and summer solstice curves have been approximated by straight lines. The meridian extends beyond both solstices the length of the diameter of the inner circle.

generalInformation.note: The fragments were found in 1814 on the Vigna Cassini near the Via Appia, Rome. Peter dates marble and epigraphy (lunate c and e) to the period of Antonius Pius (ca. 138 A.D.).

generalInformation.description: Both these marble fragments seem to be parts of the same dial although the two pieces are of different thicknesses.

generalInformation.description: One side of this flat stone is inscribed with part of a sundial and wind rose. The solstices, equinox, and signs of the zodiac are identified in Latin. The reverse side of the stone is inscribed as a gameboard.

generalInformation.note: Found in February, 1883, in the Mausoleum of Augustus, Rome. Only two drawings of this object are preserved, that slightly differ from each other, but most probably show the same sundial.

archive.holderInstitution: Tivoli State Art Institute Department in Via Giuseppe Mazzini
archive.holderDepartment: Tiny wooded area behind the institute

generalInformation.description: Catamo: The usual parameters  give a latitude of 45° (Tivoli is at 42°) and a perpendicular height for the gnomon of 36 mm. The directions and the distances measured from the projection of the gnomon point on the plane at the extremities of the hour lines on the three day curves (see figure) show discrepancies, albeit not large ones, from those obtained by calculation. As a whole, it seems to be a sundial of average accuracy. When it was first discovered, traces of lead and iron were found in the hole for the gnomon, which was some way from the correct position, suggesting that the rod was bent or curved so that its tip would be in the right position. At some time - it is impossible to know exactly when, but certainly after the discovery - a strongly curved iron gnomon was fixed in it with lead, but this is out of square.

dialfaces.inscriptions: A Latin inscription above and below dial grid reads: T \cdot HERENNIVS\cdot L \cdot F// T \cdot HERENNIVS\cdot T \cdot F// IIII \cdot VIR \cdot IVR \cdot DIC\cdot RES(TIT)

generalInformation.inscriptions: Gibbs: A Latin inscription above and below dial grid reads: T \cdot HERENNIVS\cdot L \cdot F// T \cdot HERENNIVS\cdot T \cdot F// IIII \cdot VIR \cdot IVR \cdot DIC\cdot RES(TIT).
generalInformation.note: Seen by Mommsen in the Villa Gregoriana in 1847. Found near Tivoli, Italy, during tunneling for diversion of river Aniene in 1832.

generalInformation.description: A stump of iron gnomon remains in position. The fragment is approximately half a dial with seven hour lines (5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and three day curves preserved. The meridian extends from the top of the fragment to some distance beyond the winter solstice.

dialfaces.description: A stump of iron gnomon remains in position. The fragment is approximately half a dial with seven hour lines (5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) and three day curves preserved. The meridian extends from the top of the fragment to some distance beyond the winter solstice.

generalInformation.note: Found in 1961 by Mr. Charles Leva at the Gallo-Roman village of Evelette near Huy in Belgium.

generalInformation.description: Parts of eight hour lines are preserved on this triangular fragment (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10). Complete hour lines do not extend beyond solstices, but meridian does continue beyond these bounds. Solstice curves seem to be approximate; equinox and hour lines are creditably straight. At the junction of meridian and engraved lower border of the fragment an interesting group of engraved lines is visible. It consists of two straight lines intersecting the meridian in the same point at angles of 24 on the left and 22 on the right. In addition, two engraved circles with centers can be seen on either side of the meridian tangent to these straight lines and the meridian.

generalInformation.note: Freson reports seeing hole along meridian 11 mm from summer solstice suitable for holding a perpendicular gnomon. This hole is not visible in the published photograph.

generalInformation.description: The round gnomon hole, 8 mm in diameter, contains traces of bronze and iron. A hole for possible mounting is visible in the back at top center. The stone is shaped like a truncated pyramid with the dial engraved on the base with the larger surface area. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are visible. Lines for the fifth and seventh hours split into two lines just below the equinox.

generalInformation.note: Listed as quarry mark from Mons Claudianus in the eastern desert of Egypt.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: The equinox is a horizontal straight line as it should be for all latitudes between equator and pole. As plane sections of sunlight cones, the day curves should be parts of hyperbolas for latitudes above the torrid zone. The curve closest to the projection of the gnomon point on the vertical face is that traced by the shadow of the gnomon point on winter solstice. The day curve at winter solstice is limited by a horizontal line passing through the projection of the gnomon point. In spring and summer, the shadow of a gnomon point will fall on a south-facing vertical dial for only part of the day. An additional north-facing vertical dial with its own gnomon point is required for marking some of the seasonal hours between the spring and autumn equinox. It seems likely that the designer of the south (and north) face of the Tower of Winds determind the pattern of hour lines and day curves by constructing seasonal hour points on the dial face and joining them. The Ptolemaic coordinates relevant to the construction of prime vertical sundials are the vertical and horarius arcs. (p. 43) If the vertical dials on the eight sides of Andronicu´s Tower of Winds in Athens were engraved at the time the tower was built, they belong to the first century B.C. (p.78 f) Some time during the first century B.C. Andronicus Cyrrhestes designed and built an octagonal tower on which eight planar sundials are visible today (see Vitruvius, De architectura I, 6.4). The dials face the principal points of the compass. (p. 342)  Schaldach: Achteckiges Gebäude. Unter einem flachen Pyramidendach befinden sich durch ihre Namen gekennzeichnet - die Reliefs der Windgötter, männliche geflügelte Wesen, die sich dem Betrachter im Halbprofil zuwenden. Darunter ist auf jeder Wand über ihre gesamte Breite das Liniennetz einer Vertikaluhr aufgetragen. Der Bau ist, mit einer Höhe von13,5 m und einer Wandbreite von 3,3 m auf jeder Seite, über einer dreistufigen Krepis äußerst präzise nach den Himmelsrichtungen orientiert. An der NO- und NW-Seite sind die beiden Eingänge mit kurzen rechteckigen Portikus. Von den drei kleinen Fenstern auf der N-, W- und S-Seite ist keines original. Kernstück der Inneneinrichtung war eine Wasseruhr, von der nur mehr das innere Becken und die Zu- und Ablaufrinnen erkennbar sind.

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: Gnomon hole is visible along meridian above horizon line. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are preserved. An allegorical relief and the Greek inscription  νòτος    are visible above the dial face.  Schaldach: Das Befestigungsloch für den Gnomon befindet sich in der Symmetrieachse der Zeichnung über dem Sims, der die Uhren von den Reliefs der Windgötter abgrenzt. Zum Sonnenaufgang fällt die Schattenspitze des Gnomons auf Fuge 13, vom Betrachter aus gesehen links vom Schattenstab. Fuge 13 steht dort für den Anfang der ersten Stunde. Daran schließt sich  gegen den Uhrzeigersinn drehend als weitere Stundenlinie jene an, die das Ende der ersten Stunde markiert. Sie endet an der Kante zu SW-Wand und trifft dort mit der horizontalen Äquinoktiallinie zusammen. Das gleiche Bild zeigt sich an der Kante zur SO-Wand. Hier ist es die Stundenlinie für das Ende der elften Stunde, die auf die Äquinoktiallinie zuläuft. Die Stundenlinien für das Ende der zweiten und dritten, sowie der neunten und zehnten Stunde werden durch die Kanten der Wand begrenzt. Nur die Linien für die vierte bis achte Stunde erstrecken sich vollständig zwischen Winterwendlinie und Sommerwendlinie. Die Größe des Liniennetzes ist eine Folge der Schattenstabslänge. In der Symmetrieachse der Schattenfläche liegt die Mittagslinie, die zugleich das Ende der sechsten und den Beginn der siebten Stunde bedeutet. Die Sonnenuntergangslinie ist die Verlängerung der Sonnenaufgangslinie und liegt rechts vom Schattenstab.
dialfaces.inscriptions: νóτος

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: Five hour lines mark the first to the fifth hours of the day between the engraved summer and winter solstices. An engraved equinox crosses the hour lines between the solstices. An allegorical relief and the Greek inscription  ἀπηλι’ωτης  decorates the dial face.  Schaldach: Die Sommerwendlinien werden nach oben in ein Eck gezogen, nach unten enden sie bei Fuge 8. Die anderen Datumslinien werden an der Außenkante geführt, wobei die Winterwendlinie bei Fuge 10, die Äquinoktiallinie bei Fuge 8 endet.
dialfaces.inscriptions: ἀπηλι’ωτης

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: A square gnomon hole is visible along the horizon at a point 9.85 from the meridian. Five hour lines are engraved. The meridian coincides with an edge of the octangonal tower. Solstices and equinox cross the hour lines. An allegorical relief and the Greek inscription  ϵ<’υρος  are visible above the dial face.  Schaldach: Die SO-Uhr gibt die sechs Vormittagsstunden wieder. Die Mittagslinie wird jeweils durch die nördliche Kante gebildet. Die Sommerwendlinien beginnen bei der südlichen Kante in Fuge 13 und enden an der nördliche Kanter bei Fuge 8. Das Linienbild wird dadurch der Wand in einer Weise angepasst, wie es kaum besser möglich gewesen wäre. Auf der SO-Seite  geht die Sommerwendlinie mit 2,5 cm nur wenig über die Fuge 8 hinaus, dafür wird die Kante zur S-Wand um 8 cm verfehlt.
dialfaces.inscriptions: ϵ<’υρος

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: The gnomon hole is positioned along a line perpendicular to the horizon line which intersects the equinox. Four engraved hour lines and a horizon line are crossed by the winter solstice, the equinox, and the summer solstice. One hour line intersects the winter solstice; three hour lines intersect the summer solstice. An allegorical relief and a Greek inscription  καικìας  decorate the dial face.  Schaldach: Die NO-Uhr erhält Licht in den letzten vier Morgenstunden. Die Linien fallen nicht so weit, weil sich die Giebel der Portale anschließen. Die Äquinoktiallinien verlaufen gerade, auch die Winterwendlinien ebenso wie die Sommerwendlinie im Bereich der fünften und siebten Stunde. Die Äquinoktiallinien zielen auf den Schnittpunkt von äußerer Kante und Fuge 9. Die Linie gerät aber bei der NO-Uhr etwas zu hoch. Das Steinraster hätte das gleiche konstruktive Bild wie bei der NW-Uhr ermöglicht.
dialfaces.inscriptions: καικíας

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: A gnomon hole can be seen along the meridian line above the horizon. Two hour lines and the summer solstice are engraved. An allegorical relief and a Greek inscription  βορéας  decorate the block above the shadow-receiving surface.  Schaldach: Die N-Uhr weist mit der Sommerwendlinie lediglich eine Datumslinie auf, denn nur in den Sommermonaten erreicht das Licht der ersten und der letzten zwei Stunden  des Tages die Schattenfläche. Die Linien für das Ende der ersten und der  11. Sunde sind über die Sommerwendlinie hinaus bis zum theoretischen Fußpunkt des Schattenstabs gezeichnet worden und sogar eine Verlängerung der zweiten und der zehnten Stundenlinie wurde angebracht, obwohl der gesamte Bereich ständig im Schatten des Turms liegt.
dialfaces.inscriptions: βορéας

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: Stuart and Revette took no measurements of this face, but the dial is similar to that engraved on the Northeast Face. An allegorical relief and the Greek inscription  οκ’ιρων  decorate the block above the shadow-receiving surface.   Schaldach: Die NW-Uhr erhält Licht in den letzten vier Abendstunden. Die Linien fallen nicht so weit, weil sich die Giebel der Portale anschließen. Die Äquinoktiallinien verlaufen gerade, auch die Winterwendlinien ebenso wie die Sommerwendlinie im Bereich der fünften und siebten Stunde. Die Äquinoktiallinien zielen auf den Schnittpunkt von äußerer Kante und Fuge 9.
dialfaces.inscriptions: οκíρων

dialfaces.description: Stuart and Revette took no measurements of this face, but the dial is similar to that engraved on the East Face. An allegorical relief above the shadow-receiving surface is inscribed  [ξ]é[Φυροσ].
dialfaces.inscriptions: [ξ]é[Φυροσ]

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: Stuart and Revette took no measurements of this face, but the dial is similar to that engraved on the Southeast Face. An allegorical relief above the shadow-receiving surface is inscribed  λ’ιψ.   Schaldach: Die SW-Uhr gibt die sechs Nachmittagsstunden wieder. Die Mittagslinie wird durch die nördliche Kante gebildet. Die Sommerwendlinien beginnen bei der südlichen Kante in Fuge 13 und enden an der nördlichen Kante bei Fuge 8.
dialfaces.inscriptions: λíψ

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: A small partially preserved cylindrical chamber with radius equal to 148 cm extends from the south face of the octagonal tower. On the outer surface of the cylinder, two sets of intersecting lines (meeting at angles of 52) are visible engraved at the sides, perhaps forming part of a ninth dial. In the figures below ABC is the horizontal section of the cylinder. DD´´ is the lateral surface of the cylinder showing the engraved lines. Schaldach: Vom zylindrischen Anbau an der S-Seite des Turms sind nur noch wenige Steinschichten erhalten. Sie tragen an der östlichen  und symmetrisch dazu, an der westlichen Rundung die Reste einer leicht gekrümmten, fallenden Linie sowie  einer vertikalen Linie, die beide aufeinander zulaufen und sich unter einem Winkel von etwa 30 treffen. Betrachtet man den mittäglichen Schattenwurf des Vorsprungs am Tag der Sommersonnenwende, so schneidet dieser die vertikale Ost- bzw. Westlinie im tiefsten Punkt. Dass die Schattenlinie selbst mit der gekrümmten Linie identifiziert werden kann scheidet jedoch aus, da die Abweichung von den vermessenen Punkten zu groß ist. Vielmehr zeigt die Berechnung, dass die Linie als Ortslinie der Schnittpunkte von zwei Schattenlinien zu sehen ist. Die eine begrenzt den Eigenschatten des zylindrischen Bauwerks, die andere den Schatten des Vorsprungs.

dimensions.note: bei optimaler Anpassung, senkrecht stehendem Gnomon

generalInformation.description: The position and measurements of the gnomon holes are shown in the accompanying diagram. No metal remains. This dial is a combination of four deviating vertical dials. On all faces, the hour lines have been engraved less heavily than the day curves. The equinox appears to have been engraved last.

dialfaces.description: Five engraved hour lines, not including the meridian, and three day curves have been preserved.
dialfaces.inscriptions: A Greek inscription remains on the left southwest-facing surface:  Fa?d??? ????? // ?a?a???? p???.

dialfaces.description: Five engraved hour lines, not including the meridian, and three day curves are preserved. The meridian is formed by the intersection of left southeast face and right southwest face.
Four engraved hour lines, not including the meridian, and three day curves are preserved. The meridian is formed by the intersection of the left southeast and the right southwest face.
Five engraved hour lines, not including the meridian, and three day curves are preserved. The meridian is formed by the right edge of the block.

generalInformation.inscriptions: A Greek inscription remains on the left southwest-facing surface:  Φαῖδρος Ζωíλου // Παιανιϵùς éποíϵι.
generalInformation.note: Purchased from Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Eleven scratched hour lines are connected by two semi-circles at the top and bottom; hour lines do not extend beyond curved boundaries. The left edge is finished smoothly at the top and bears a trace of curved molding. With the help of a strong light it is possible to see scratched Greek letters near the outer circle. Schaldach: Die unregelmäßigen Stundenlinien erstrecken sich zwischen zwei konzentrischen halbkreisförmigen Linien mit Radien von etwa 20,5 cm und 3 cm. Der Fund ist nach allen Seiten hin abgebrochen, deshalb ist der große Halbkreis nur zum Teil vorhanden. Der kleine Halbkreis ist schwach ausgebildet. Er wird von einigen Stundenlinien gekreuzt, deren Verlängerungen sich nicht in einem gemeinsamen Punkt reffen, weshalb keine genauen Stundenwinkel angegeben werden können. Innerhalb der Sektoren und in der Nähe der äußeren Kreislinie sind noch Reste der Buchstaben A, B und G zur Benennung der Stunden zu erkennen.

dialfaces.description: Gibbs: Eleven scratched hour lines are connected by two semi-circles at the top and bottom; hour lines do not extend beyond curved boundaries. The left edge is finished smoothly at the top and bears a trace of curved molding. The angles formed by hour lines are from left to right: 17.5, 15.5, 15, 13, 14.5, 15.5, 14.5, 14, 15.5, 11.5, 15.5, and 18.  Schaldach: Die unregelmäßigen Stundenlinien erstrecken sich zwischen zwei konzentrischen halbkreisförmigen Linien mit Radien von etwa 20,5 cm und 3 cm. generalInformation.inscriptions: Greek letters near the outer circle:  ΑΒΓΔΕ
generalInformation.note: Found June 25, 1951, in marble pile north of the Temple of Ares in the Greek Agora, Athens./The angles formed by hour lines are from left to right: 17.5, 15.5, 15, 13, 14.5, 15.5, 14.5, 14, 15.5, 11.5, 15.5, and 18.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Seven hour lines, meeting at a hole at the top, and joined by a broken line resembling a quarter circle at the bottom, form this dial grid. A scraped area to the right of the meridian may indicate either preparation for the completion of the dial or destruction of part of the grid. Broneer remarks that the ruined odium at Corinth was used for private dwellings in the third and fourth centuries A.D.; the scratched dial probably dates from this period. The hour lines measure from left to right: 125 mm, 119 mm, 118 mm, 122 mm, 119 mm, 125 mm, 130 mm. These hour lines form the following angles, measure from left to right: 15.5, 14.5, 13, 10.5, 14, 15.5.  Schaldach: Die 6 Stundenlinien in einem leicht geglätteten Bereich des Steins haben eine Länge von etwa 130 mm und treffen sich etwas unterhalb des Gnomonlochs. Die umgrenzten fünf Sektoren haben Winkelgrößen von (ab Mittagslinie gemessen): 18, 14, 11, 14; 14.  Bei der von Gibbs genannten siebten Stundenlinie handelt es sich vermutlich um eine nur angedeutete Linie im Feld der ersten Stunde. Die Fläche ist nicht genau nach Süden orientiert, sondern weicht leicht nach Osten ab. Die Uhr ist erst entstanden, nachdem die Gänge zu den Zuschauerräumen zerstört und die Schattenfläche der Sonne am Vormittag ausgesetzt war. Der Verfall des Odeons begann im 2. Jh., vom 3. Jh. Bis  ins 5.Jh. sind private Nutzungen nachgewiesen (Broneer, S. 140).

generalInformation.note: The hour lines measure from left to right: 125 mm, 119 mm, 118 mm, 122 mm, 119 mm, 125 mm, 130 mm. These hour lines form the following angles, measure from left to right: 15.5, 14.5, 13, 10.5, 14, 15.5.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: A gnomon hole 18 mm square and 18 mm deep is preserved in the top surface of the dial above the meridian. Its sides are oriented parallel to and perpendicular to the sloping edge which intersects the edge of the dial surface at an angle of 142.8. A slight depression leads from this hole towards the sloping edge. There is no metal in the hole or the groove. Three fragments have been joined to form this southwest facing dial surface. The finished left edge of the slab is formed by a sloping surface which intersects the dial surface at an angle of 142.8. Top and bottom edges are smoothly finished and a section of the right edge smoothly follows the curve of the summer solstice. Five engraved hour lines have been preserved in addition to the meridian which is formed by the intersecting planes of the left edge. Three day curves extend from the meridian to the top edge. Two clamp holes and grooves are preserved in the rough picked back along the unbroken meridian edge.  Schaldach: Die vertikale SW-Uhr ist aus drei Teilen wieder zusammengefügt und zeigt eine fast vollständig erhaltene Schattenfläche für die Nachmittagsstunden. Die Stundenlinien sind gleichmäßig tief und breit gezogen. Die Kantenfläche, welche mit der Vorderfläche die Mittagslinie formt, ist zweifach abgeschrägt. Der Neigungswinkel zur Schattenfläche beträgt 40 bis 45 bei einer Länge von etwa 68 mm. Die anschließende Schräge hat eine Länge von etwa 35 mm. Auf der grob behauenen Rückseite befinden sich entlang der Kantenlinie zwei Klammerlöcher. Die obere Kantenfläche ist gleichmäßig eben mit einem Loch unweit der Ecke von 18 mm Durchmesser und 18 mm Tiefe und bildet mit der Vorderfläche die Sonnenunterganglinie. Die zweite, zum großen Teil abgebrochene Seitenfläche zeigt den Rest einer gebogenen Kante. Glasers Überlegung, dass alle vier Wände, also auch die SO-Wand, die NO-Wand und die NW-Wand des Bauwerks eine Sonnenuhr besaßen, wird durch das Fragment einer SO-Uhr unterstützt, welches Gibbs im Amphiareion noch vorfand (5006G), aber weder durch Glaser in den Jahren 1973-78, noch durch mich in 2001 aufgefunden wurde. Die abgefaste Kante, im Winkel von 40-45, ist nicht so fein abgearbeitet wie die Schattenfläche mit den Linien.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: This fragment is the upper left corner of a southeast-facing dial. Top and lower edges are finished smooth. Three engraved hour lines (1, 2, 3) and three day curves are preserved. All planes of the slab surface intersect at right angles.  Schaldach: Glasers Überlegung, dass alle vier Wände, also auch die SO-Wand, die NO-Wand und die NW-Wand des Bauwerks eine Sonnenuhr besaßen, wird durch das Fragment einer SO-Uhr unterstützt, welches Gibbs im Amphiareion noch vorfand (5006G), aber weder durch Glaser in den Jahren 1973-78, noch durch mich in 2001 aufgefunden wurde.

dialfaces.description: This fragment is the upper left corner of a southeast-facing dial. Top and lower edges are finished smooth. Three engraved hour lines (1, 2, 3) and three day curves are preserved. All planes of the slab surface intersect at right angles.

generalInformation.description: The base of a bronze gnomon in lead fill remains in the top surface above the meridian formed by the intersecting dial surfaces. This well-preserved dial consists of two dial surfaces, each with five engraved hour lines and three day curves, meeting at the meridian; one surface faces southeast, the other southwest. Some hour lines on the right extend beyond the summer solstice, but all seem to be contained within the winter curve.

Some hour lines on the right extend beyond the summer solstice, but all seem to be contained within the winter curve.

generalInformation.note: Found south of the oikos of Dionysos on Delos. Donna observes (p. 195) that the engraved lines of the equinox and the summer solstice continue onto the top cross section. I did not observe these lines.

generalInformation.description: The drawing in Deonna shows fourteen hour lines. Part of an engraved circular curve is visible at lower left. The hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole to the circular arc.

dialfaces.description: The drawing in Deonna shows fourteen hour lines. Part of an engraved circular curve is visible at lower left. The hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole to the circular arc.

generalInformation.description: Three day curves and six hour lines (including horizon line) are visible.

dialfaces.description: Three day curves and six hour lines (including horizon line) are visible.

generalInformation.note: Found on the island of Delos near the Temple of Apollo. Reported to be in the cabinet des antiques Paris, in 1814.

generalInformation.description: A hole for a gnomon is preserved in the top of the dial directly above the meridian line; some residue of lead remains. A smooth curved edge on the right side follows the curve of the summer solstice. Five fairly deeply incised hour lines do not continue beyond either solstice curve. The right edge is finished in a double concave molding. There is no trace of color, relief decoration, or inscription. Gibbs's illustration is slightly distorted and differs from real object.

The right edge is finished in a double concave molding. There is no trace of color, relief decoration, or inscription.

generalInformation.description: The combination of grooves at the top center of this dial block presumably held the gnomon. Eleven fairly deeply scratched hour lines divide a single semicircle into twelve parts on this dial. The shadow-receiving surface is uniformly thick and smoothly finished. The hour lines measure from left to right: 130, 131, 132, 132, 132, 130, 134, 135, 136, 135, 132 mm. They form the following angles, measured from the left to the right horizon: 10.8, 18, 15, 15.4, 15.8, 15, 12, 15.8, 16, 20.5, 16, 9.7.

generalInformation.description: Five deeply engraved hour lines, the equinox, and the winter solstices remain on this dial fragment. The meridian is not preserved.

dialfaces.description: Five deeply engraved hour lines, the equinox, and the winter solstices remain on this dial fragment. The meridian is not preserved.

generalInformation.description: Two preserved holes may have served separately or together as gnomon holders. One hole in the top of the dial is filled with lead and connected to the right edge by a groove 85 mm deep. A second hole, 10 mm wide, is situated 34 mm from the top along the right edge sloping up at an angle of 45. Six engraved hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on this southeast-facing half of a vertical deviating dial. The equinox and two solstices do not extend beyond the first hour line. Although the dial has been squared off along the left edge, a portion of the curved border remains. The top and right edge are smoothly perpendicular to the dial face. A large engraved B is preserved at the left end of the top edge. Evidence at the junctures of the wide hour lines and the equinox indicates that the former were engraved last.

dialfaces.description: Two preserved holes may have served separately or together as gnomon holders. One hole in the top of the dial is filled with lead and connected to the right edge by a groove 85 mm deep. A second hole, 10 mm wide, is situated 34 mm from the top along the right edge sloping up at an angle of 45. Six engraved hour lines, including the meridian, are preserved on this southeast-facing half of a vertical deviating dial. The equinox and two solstices do not extend beyond the first hour line. Although the dial has been squared off along the left edge, a portion of the curved border remains. The top and right edge are smoothly perpendicular to the dial face. A large engraved B is preserved at the left end of the top edge. Evidence at the junctures of the wide hour lines and the equinox indicates that the former were engraved last.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: The engraved lines on this dial face include five hour lines, the winter solstice, the equinox, and the summer solstice. The dial appears to have been made to face southeast.  Severino: Scheda del museo : N° 2 lastre di marmo bianco, centinate ad un quarto di cerchio da un lato con la parte in piano incisa con 5 segni messi nel senso dell’angolo a raggiungere l’altro segno fatto in modo da seguire la curva spezzata nella parte centrale e partente da un lato a raggiungere l’altro, tali incisioni sono 3, nello spessore delle lastre e cioè nell parte centinata ove vanno a convergere le linee vi sono dei segni fatti per misura m. 0,72 x 0.55 x 0.028. Spezzata in 13 frammenti. Provenienza Nemi (Valle Giardino). Entrata al museo in marzo-febbraio 1925. Ammissione Aprile 1931. Prezzo £. 50. Vecchia collocazione, Olearie, settore 19 A 2° ripiano. La descrizione è fatta ovviamente da una persona completamente estranea alla gnomonica ed all’astronomia in genere. E’ importante notare che la scheda cataloga in un unico numero di inventario, il 112134, due lastre di marmo che si crede appartenenti ad un unico reperto. In realtà le due lastre di marmo rappresentano due meridiane verticali declinanti complementari, ben distinte. Una occidua, l’altra ortiva. Alla seconda lastra che rappresenta la meridian occidua e che doveva essere posizionata a 90 gradi circa (ad angolo retto) con la presente, le daremo convenzionalmente e provvisoriamente il numero di inventario 112134 bis, per distinguerla dal primo reperto. Continuando con le annotazione, rileviamo che questa meridiana è stata pubblicata anche da Gibbs al numero del suo catalogo 5016 per la quale ripete quanto diceva già l’Antonini al numero 10 che era stata vista in Casa De Angelis a Tivoli. Fatto sta che al Museo ci è arrivata proveniente da Nemi.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Marucchi describes a configuration of four engraved lines which he suggests served to mark the positions of the third and ninth hours of the day between winter and summer solstice.   A.L.F.Jr.: This sun-dial was different from any hitherto known, in having not one but six gnomons, one for each hour, and consequently for each line, at the extremity of which it was placed; while in the centre there must have been a vertical one for mid-day. These metal styles threw their shadow down their line at the corresponding hour, but the correspondence was perfect only during equinoctial days. It would be necessary to annex a plate in order to follow the calculations by which the writer proves his position.

generalInformation.description: A blood red color marks the eleven preserved hour lines and three day curves of this dial. There is no red color along the edges near the missing meridian line, and in fragment 7297 the left or meridian edge is finished smooth. The smooth lower edges of fragment 7297 also give some indication of the original shape of the dial. All preserved hour lines continue in red to the top center of the dial where a groove remains in fragment 7296. The two engraved hour lines in fragment 7297 continue beyond the lower day curve without red color. Note that while the hour lines are straight lines, the day curves are broken lines, the top curve most closely resembling a semicircle. The hour lines form the following angles between the left horizon and the eleventh hour: 19, 18, 15.5, 17.2, 14.1, 11, 10, 11, 14.7, 12.8, 17.5. The winter solstice curve consists of the following arcs: 9, 11, 9, 10, 8,,, 8, 11, 8, 10,  mm. The equinox curve between the horizon and the third hour line consists of the following arcs: 25, 26, 20 mm. The summer solstice curve between the sixth and eighth hour lines measures: 37, 31 mm.

dialfaces.description: The preserved gnomon hole is 6 mm in diameter. Three circular arcs (with the gnomon hole as the center) are each evenly divided by eleven hour lines. Arc c_1 is approximately 103; arc c_2 is approximately 100; arc c_3 is approximately 96. The dial grid appears to have been designed to have functioned in the plane of the equator, inclined at an angle of 32 from vertical.

The south face marks the seasonal hours when the sun is south of the celestial equator in fall and winter. Two side dials with faces parallel to the meridian plane mark the equinoctial hours before and after noon. The same gnomon hole with cross section perpendicular to the equinoctial plane once held gnomons for both the north and south face. The preserved gnomon hole is 6 mm in diameter. A horizontal line crosses the dial surface 31.5 mm from the top edge. Three circular sections (with the gnomon hole as center) are evenly divided by eleven hour lines. Arc $c_4 is approximately 75.8; arc c_5 is approximately 77.6; and arc c_6 is approximately 81$.

A trace of metal remains in the gnomon hole (diameter is 4 mm). A long straight line from the gnomon to the bottom of the slab is divided into six parts by five marks. The divisions measure from top to bottom: 12 mm, 16 mm, 19 mm, 33.5 mm, 87 mm, and 152 mm.

The empty gnomon hole has diameter 4.5 mm and is 16.5 mm deep. A long straight line from the gnomon hole to the bottom of the slab is divided into six parts by five marks. The divisions measure from top to bottom: 12.5 mm, 16 mm, 20 mm, 33 mm, 87 mm, and 150 mm.

generalInformation.description: Gibbs: Lost; Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west. Unfortunately attempts to locate it in the museum´s study collection on the summer of 1971 were unsuccessful. Bonanome: It is disc-shaped with two flat surfaces, only slightly raised with respect to the outer rim. The corbel at the base gives its vertical position, and there is still a trace of the sockets used to secure it to an underlying support – now lost – to assure elevation and visibility. The flat surfaces of this solar instrument have been carved and “rubricated” (i.e., coloured in red) to make their reading easier, since they acted as sequential dials. This means that a dial is designed to be faced to the East, in order to show the morning hours, whereas the other is faced to the West and shows the afternoon hours.; Adam/Severino: Three day curves and six hour lines (including horizon line) are visible.

dialfaces.description: Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west.
Photographs of this dial (negative numbers 54820 and 54821) indicate that it consists of a vertical disk facing east and west.

Bonanome: The flat surfaces of this solar instrument have been carved and rubricated (i.e., colored in red) to make their reading easier, since they acted as sequential dials. This means that a dial is designed to be faced to the East, in order to show the morning hours, whereas the other is faced to the West and shows the afternoon hours. On both surfaces, a mirrored pattern of vertical and horizontal lines called analemma reproduces the part of the daylight hours corresponding to the East and West cardinal points. The line AEB marks the horizon, from where three different lines start. Two lateral hyperbolas, slightly declining, AA and BB mark the course of time during the solstitial period: it is shorter in the summer solstice (AA) around the 21st June, when the sun is on the highest point above the horizon, and longer in the winter solstice (BB), around the 23rd December, when the sun is on the lowest point above the horizon. Between those two lines there is the equinoctial line (EEE), relating to the days of the spring equinox of the 21st March, and to the autumnal equinox of the 23rd September. This line is more or less inclined depending on the cardinal point the dial is facing. The six horizontal secant lines, starting from AEB and ending to AEB, after being calibrated on the Eastern and Western dials, mark the six sectors in which the hours are divided: in ante meridiem (a.m.) and post meridiem (p.m.) respectively. As we can see in the drawing, these six lines marking the passing of time are more clustered near the noon line because the sun moves slower in that phase. Therefore, the hour could be read looking at the tip of the shadow cast on the dial by the gnomon or style (that is the metallic element placed in a pre-arranged point of the analemma) which follows the motion of the sun across the sky. To determine the length, the position (orthogonal or inclined), the insertion point of the gnomon along the line AEB which marks the horizon, and to draw the declining segments crossed by the secant lines of the hours of the analemma, complex gnomonic calculations are required. In the sundial we are discussing on, two gnomons have been placed halfway along the horizontal line AEB. Of these gnomons, only the pins still inserted in the marble slab and the lead used to solder them remain visible. Another characteristic of this sundial is the presence of a third gnomon. Similarly to the two other, it is marked by the soldering lead still present on the outer rim of the marble frame. Its insertion angle is particularly acute, probably due to the need of being in axis with the sun at noon of the equinoctial days. This, in turn, was probably devised to make calibration and periodic checks of the instrument easier. However, at a closer examination, one can see that in the insertion point of this gnomon two straight carved lines intersect. They were once rubricated and are perpendicular: the vertical line is longer than the horizontal one because the dial border does not limit it. One can also see that the horizontal line must have continued to be overlapped onto the horizontal line of the Eastern analemma. Vice versa, the latter should have continued to reach the unfortunately damaged horizontal line of the Western dial. Since the point where the lines on the rim intersect is exactly the same as that of the third gnomon, it is more correct to believe that this system could have been used to follow the motion of the gnomons shadow from one dial to the other. In other words, this system gave the observer the opportunity to read the time from below also during the delicate passage from the ante meridiem to the post meridiem position of the sun.

generalInformation.description: Some lead remains in the gnomon hole in the top surface of this dial. The shadow-receiving surface of this dial is supported by a bull´s head and horns. The rounded back of the dial has the shape of a “feminine idol from the early bronze age.” Eleven hour lines radiate from the gnomon hole across two engraved day curves to the lower edge. The dial´s top surface slopes downward about 15 from horizontal. In making my calculations I have assumed that the summer solstice coincides with the lower edge of the cylindrical surface. Ionescu-Carligel assumes that the two engraved day curves are summer solstice and equinox. He obtains g= 166.7 mm, \phi = 44.7.   Bodenache: Auf einem massiven, breitstirnigen, schön stilisierten Stierkopf eine halbkreisförmige, konkave Sonnenuhr mit radialer und kreisbogenförmiger Unterteilung, die zur Stundenangabe diente. Trotz der oberen Beschädigung ist noch die Stelle zu erkennen, wo der Stab befestigt war, der den Schatten warf.

generalInformation.description: A very fine example of a roofed spherical dial has been found on the island of Tenos (7OO1G) with an inscription identifying it as the work of Andronicus Cyrrestes, the architect who designed the Tower of Winds in Athens in the first century B.C. No other examples of this type of dial are known in Greece or Asia Minor. The dial includes both spherical and planar faces. Four separate shadow-receiving surfaces face the cardinal points of the compass on this dial. The base below the south-facing surface is flanked by two dolphins. The area below the north-facing surface is inscribed with a lengthy Greek dedication. Three fragments have been restored (probably incorrectly) to the top of the sphere.

dialfaces.description: Seven hour lines (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9) and five day curves are preserved on the unrestored portion of this face. The configuration of lines suggests that the restoration as a roofed spherical dial is correct. Although this face of the dial is badly worn, the hour lines do seem to have once extended from the winter solstice to the summer solstice. The seasonal indicators c_1 and c_2, extending only between the fifth and seventh hour lines are marked. Three fragments have been restored (probably incorrectly) to the top of the sphere. At c_1 the solar longitude is Libra 28; at c_2 the solar longitude is Taurus 6. Geminus reports that Democritus observed the Pleiades on the fourth day of Scorpio; Euktemon observed the morning rising of the Pleiades on the thirteenth day of Taurus.

generalInformation.description: The designer of the Prosymna globe included a north-facing network of lines which also utilizes the sunlight-shadow boundary as it passes through the hour holes used with the south face. Again intersection between appropriately marked boundary and day curve marked the hour. The resulting network is appropriately similar to the network on a roofed spherical dial, for the shadow boundaries which determine the one are orthogonal to the rays of sunlight which cast an image of the sun on the other. A third network of lines stretches between the east and west hour holes across a shallow hole in the globe´s meridian. I interpret it as a secondary south-facing map of the moving boundary between sunlight and shadow. The three great semicircles which form part of the network are divided by points which would lie along the hourly positions of the boundary at winter solstice (lower semicircle), equinox (middle semicircle), and summer solstice (upper semicircle). Three separate networks of lines have been engraved on this spherical stone. Two great circles on the sphere correspond to the meridian and horizon circles. A conical hole with base 100 mm in diameter pierces the globe at the lower pole.

dialfaces.description: Upper south face: Eleven hour lines extend between summer solstice (at top) and winter solstice (at bottom). Five day curves cross the hour lines. The first and last holes are at the junctions of the horizon and the prime vertical. The middle hole is at the junction of the meridian and the prime vertical. The other holes intersect hour lines. The spaces between the day curves are indentified with Greek inscription as signs of the zodiac.  Lower south face: Three great circles meet at the east and west poles. Eleven cross lines extend between the first and second great circles. Thirteen cross lines extend between the second and third great circles. Shallow holes mark the east and west points and the junction of horizon and meridian.  North face: This configuration of lines closely resembles that on the concave surface of a roofed spherical variant dial. Eleven hour lines and three day curves are visible. A shallow hole marks the meeting point of the three day curves. A two line Greek inscription is preserved below the north face.

generalInformation.description: Seven gnomon holes are visible in the top of the dial block. One is on the north-south axis near the north face. Two groups of three are positioned symmetrically above the east and west faces. Four shadow-receiving surfaces have been carved in this block: a south-facing conical surface, a north-facing conical surface, a west-facing quarter sphere, and an east-facing quarter sphere.

dialfaces.description: Seven hour lines are preserved (3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9). Three day curves are visible (winter solstice, equinox, and summer solstice). The area above the winter solstice is broken away. The hour lines do not continue beyond the summer solstice.
Six day curves cross eleven hour lines. The hour lines do not extend beyond the upper and lower day curves.

generalInformation.note: No acquisition information is available, the dial is marked Tindari 110, and the curator assumes that it was found at that site.

generalInformation.description: The dial faces are cylindrical and hemispherical. Two winged female figures hold the hemisphere in the lower position. A torch and scroll decorate each side of the upper cylinder. A stepped molding outlines the decorated areas and the shadow-receiving surface.

dialfaces.description: Restoration has obliterated any trace of a gnomon hole. Six preserved hour lines (morning hours) and the meridian cross three day curves.
Of the eleven hour lines crossing three day curves, only the meridian extends beyond the summer solstice. The day curves are not parallel to the front edge.
