La forma della meridiana sembra infatti essere quasi una stilizzazione del formato ad eclima succisum laddove negli antichi esemplari era ben evidente il taglio del blocco della pietra secondo la latitudine del luogo, mentre qui il quadrante sembra essere stato pulito da ogni inutile presenza di parti marmoree non indispensabili a favore di una maggiore maneggevolezza data da un peso complessivo minore rispetto agli antichi blocchi di pietra.

generalInformation.description: Die aus acht Fragmenten zusammengesetzte Sonnenuhr ist aus einem Kalksteinblock gearbeitet. Sie hat die Form eines Throns mit Löwenfüßen. Die Anzeigefläche hat die Form einer angeschnittenen Halbkugel, in die sieben quer verlaufende Monatslinien graviert sind. Sie werden von elf Stundenlinien geschnitten. Die Monatslinien veranschaulichen die zunächst zunehmende, dann wieder abnehmende Länge des Schattens, den der Gnomon (Schattenzeiger) in den zwölf Monaten jeweils im Verlauf eines Tages wirft. Die beiden äußeren Linien erreicht der Schatten bei der Sommer- bzw. Wintersonnenwende, die mittlere Linie bei der Tag- und Nachtgleiche im Frühling und Herbst. Der verlorene Gnomon aus Metall war in der Mitte der Rückwand mit einer Kralle mit fünf Zähnen befestigt, deren Einlassungen sich erhalten haben. Die Spitze des horizontal angebrachten Gnomon befand sich im geometrischen Zentrum der Kugel, seine Länge entsprach somit ihrem Radius. Errechnet man anhand der eingravierten Linien die geographische Breite, für die diese Sonnenuhr geschaffen wurde, erhält man eine Position zwischen 38° 28’ und 35° 51’. Diese Werte liegen recht nah bei der  Breite von 37° 10’, auf der sich Ai Khanum befindet; die Toleranz liegt bei 1°.

dialfaces.description: Die Anzeigefläche hat die Form einer angeschnittenen Halbkugel, in die sieben quer verlaufende Monatslinien graviert sind. Sie werden von elf Stundenlinien geschnitten. Die Spitze des horizontal angebrachten gnomon befand sich im geometrischen Zentrum der Kugel, seine Länge entsprach somit ihrem Radius. Errechnet man anhand der eingravierten Linien die geographische Breite, für die diese Sonnenuhr geschaffen wurde, erhält man eine Position zwischen 38° 28’ und 35° 51’. Diese Werte liegen recht nah bei der tatsächlichen Breite von 37° 10’, auf der sich Ai Khanum befindet; die Toleranz liegt bei 1°.

generalInformation.description: Die Sonnenuhr war auf einer heute verlorenen Basis befestigt, so dass der Stein eine Neigung von 37,4° zur Vertikalen hatte. Ein großes Loch von 22 cm Durchmesser verläuft rechtwinklig zu den beiden großen Flächen A und B durch den Block. In die untere Wandung des Zylinders sind parallel zu den Außenkanten zwei Kreisbögen eingraviert, so dass zwischen den Rändern der Öffnung und diesen Linien zwei Streifen entstehen, die wiederum durch quer verlaufende Linien in zwölf Zonen unterteilt sind. Der Metallstab des 15 cm langen Gnomon, dessen Schatten entsprechend der Tages- und Jahreszeit wanderte, war in der Mittelachse der zylindrischen Öffnung angebracht. Die Uhr wurde auf ihrer Basis so aufgestellt, dass die große Fläche A nach Norden und die gegenüberliegende Fläche B nach Süden ausgerichtet war. Durch die Neigung von 37,4°, die annähernd der geographischen Breite von Ai Khanum (37° 10’) entspricht, lagen die Hauptseiten des Blocks parallel zur Äquatorialebene, der Gnomon war dementsprechend parallel zur Erdachse ausgerichtet. Bei dieser Aufstellung trafen die Sonnenstrahlen je nach Jahreszeit auf die obere oder untere Seite (A bzw. B). Zur Tag- und Nachtgleiche im Frühling und im Herbst fielen die Sonnenstrahlen parallel zur Neigung der Außenflächen ein, streiften also die Ränder der zylindrischen Öffnung, ohne dass der Gnomon einen Schatten auf die Wandung warf. An den anderen Tagen des Jahres bewegte sich der Sonneneinfall in einem Bereich von etwa 24° oberhalb bzw. unterhalb der Äquatorialebene. Damit fiel das Licht von oben bzw. von unten immer weiter in die Öffnung ein. Entsprechend wanderte der Schatten des Zeigers bis zur Sommer- bzw. Wintersonnenwende auf den beiden, durch zwölf Stundenlinien unterteilten Bändern nach innen. Im Unterschied zu unserer Zeitmessung wurde die Zeit zwischen Sonnenauf- und Sonnenuntergang in der Antike unabhängig von der Jahreszeit in zwölf gleiche Stunden geteilt. So variierte je nach Jahreszeit die Länge der Tagstunden – im Sommer lang, im Winter kurz –, nicht aber ihre Anzahl. Die Sonnenuhr von Ai Khanum ist das einzige bekannte antike Exemplar einer Äquatorial-Sonnenuhr dieses Typs und damit einmalig.

Der Metallstab des 150 mm langen Gnomon, dessen Schatten entsprechend der Tages- und Jahreszeit wanderte, war in der Mittelachse der zylindrischen Öffnung angebracht. Die Uhr wurde auf ihrer Basis so aufgestellt, dass die große Fläche A nach Norden und die gegenüberliegende Fläche B nach Süden ausgerichtet war. Durch die Neigung von 37,4°, die annähernd der geographischen Breite von Ai Khanum (37° 10’) entspricht, lagen die Hauptseiten des Blocks parallel zur Äquatorialebene, der Gnomon war dementsprechend parallel zur Erdachse ausgerichtet. Bei dieser Aufstellung trafen die Sonnenstrahlen je nach Jahreszeit auf die obere oder untere Seite (A bzw. B). Zur Tag- und Nachtgleiche im Frühling und im Herbst fielen die Sonnenstrahlen parallel zur Neigung der Außenflächen ein, streiften also die Ränder der zylindrischen Öffnung, ohne dass der Gnomon einen Schatten auf die Wandung warf. An den anderen Tagen des Jahres bewegte sich der Sonneneinfall in einem Bereich von etwa 24° oberhalb bzw. unterhalb der Äquatorial-Ebene. generalInformation.description: The sundial from Myrmekion near Panticapaeum is the most pan-Roman of the unusual sculptures from the Black Sea region, being a simple version of a carved and engraved block of marble produced for villas and town-squares from Ephesus to the environs of Rome. It is in the form of about the fourth part of a hollow sphere, supported on two large feline feet. The concave surface is graduated into twelve hour spaces, and there are remains of the attachment of the gnomon.

generalInformation.description: Stone sundial, broken on the left and at the bottom right corner; decorated with the head of a bull in relief; on either side of the relief, traces of an inscription in six lines, erased in antiquity. Found in 1918 on the estate of B.A.Bok together with CIRB 942. Mentioned by Yu.Yu.Marti, Izvestija Tavricheskogo otdelenija Istoriko- arkheologicheskoj komissii 59 (Kerch 1928) fig. 21 (ph. only; inscription not visible) [non vidimus]. In a study of four sundials in the Kerch Museum, ed. pr. S.A.Shestakov, Bosporskie issledovan?a 9 (2005) 360-373, studies this sundial and the inscription (363-365 no. 2; ph.; dr.; in Russian). He suggests that the text was erased when the sundial was moved to the temple. (CIRB 942 L. 1, 234 A.D.), As the original dedicatory text was no longer appropriate. V.P.Jajlenko, Tysiacheletnij Bosporskij reich: Istorija i epigrafika Bospora (Moscow 2010) 672/673 no. 18 (ph.; dr.; in Russian), presents an independent edition (unaware of the ed.pr.)

generalInformation.description: Dettaglio dell'orologio solare verticale rappresentato in un rilievo. L'orologio è verticale e la superficie è leggermente emisferica, come negli altri esemplari che ci sono pervenuti. Qui sono descritte solo sete linee orarie convergenti tutte in un unico punto. Si tratta probabilmente solo di una rappresentazione e non di un orologio realmente funzionante.

generalInformation.note: This is not a sundial.

generalInformation.description: Procede de las excavaciones arqueológicas de la cercana ciudad romana de Segóbriga. De piedra caliza, tallado en su parte superior el cuadrante hemisférico con 11 línes incisas que dividen la cavidad en doce partes y representan los círculos horarios. No conserva el gnomon o varilla original y de dimensiones 42 x 20,5 cm. Los antiguos romanos copiaron el "scaphe" griego al que denominaron "hemisferium", no añadiendo nada nuevo con respecto a la medición del tiempo.

Si trovano 3 frammenti di orologio solare “possibilmente da collocarsi in epoca romana”. Il testo originale in spagnolo è il seguente: …Sobre el màrmol grisàceo se ha grabado la anotaciòn, “limite invernal” o “solsticio de verano” sin que se aprecian otras indicaciones horarias. La imagen ha sido obtenida de una postal editada por la Generalitat valenciana y nos ha sido facilitada por Victor Inurria.
Frammento di orologio orizzontale tipo "pelecinon" in pietra calcarea bianca. Reca parte del tracciato gnomonico intero con le linee solstiziali, in verità molto approssimative.

Two large fragments of a white marble Roman cut spherical sundial, were found in the course of building work. By putting the two pieces together it was possible to reconstruct the sundial, although the upper part of the noon hour line is missing.

dialfaces.description: The absence of much of the noon hour line makes the usual calculations difficult. By a fairly easy reconstruction, however, the summer solstice curve gives an intended latitude of 32° while the winter solstice curve gives one of 34°. Both are very far from that of the site where the sundial was found, which is 42°. The angle between the oblique front and the rear vertical plane, which is 35°, shows the same discrepancy, but agrees quite closely with the calculated latitude. There are eleven hour lines, with hour-points satisfactorily equidistant, while the solstice curves are almost equidistant from the equinox line – 95 mm and 101 mm respectively. From an analysis of the sum of the data measured and calculated, this sundial seems to be well cut but not without constructional irregularities.

generalInformation.note: Now in private ownership.

generalInformation.description: The base is carved with a cyma recta  S shaped molding. The dials reading concave surface is designed on the basis of a cone, in the form of a circular equilateral triangle with sides 0.46. Cone Diameter: 0.46, Cone height: 0.40. The axis of the cone is at the angle of 30 degrees from the horizontal; thus its base and the reading conical surface are tilted 60 degrees from horizontal plane. The lower surface is cut off by the cone at 194.5 degrees of a circle that is as a horse shoe, shaped arc of 12 out of 22 sections of the circle. The 12 hour sections are marked on the reading surface with 11 lines, which meet 0.035 above the dials upper surface, clearly off the axis of the cone.

generalInformation.description: Byzantine hemicyclium.
Byzantine hemicyclium.

Portable Hemicyclium "Herodian House". Exhibit 3a- The sundial. A stick, or pointer, had rested in the groove on top. The shadow cast by the sun would indicate the time. This sundial was found in the remains of Temple stones. It is believed that it was used in the Bais HaMikdash to mark the time. Exhibit 3b- The base of the sundial. It is one of the very rare depictions of the menorah made while the Bais HaMikdash was still standing.

generalInformation.description: Fors si tratta di una variante alla classima meridiana sferica a tetto, ma il tracciato orario sembra confermare che sia proprio cosi’. Sono visibili 8 linee orarie, la linea equinoziale centrale rispetto al tracciato orario e il piccolo cerchio (in corrispondenza del solstizio infernale) da cui si dipartono le linee orarie. Non si anno altri dati. Ringrazio Luca per la disponibilità e la foto della meridiana finora sconosciuta.

dialfaces.description: Sono visibili 8 linee orarie, la linea equinoziale centrale rispetto al tracciato orario e il piccolo cerchio (in corrispondenza del solstizio infernale) da cui si dipartono le linee orarie. Non si anno altri dati.

generalInformation.description: Raffaele Farese con il quale ho potuto stabilier una collaborazione reciproca che ha portato alla divulgazione nel nostro ambito gnomonico di questa meridiana di pregevole fattura. In linea di massima si tratta di una meridiana sferica con undici linee orarie temporali e tre linee solstiziali. E’ conservata ottimamente e non presenta particolari fregi sulla base. Sul retro, in prossimità del punto di convergenza delle linee orarie, è visibile un foro che serviva probabilmente all’incastro dello gnomone orizzontale.

dialfaces.description: Raffaele Farese con il quale ho potuto stabilier una collaborazione reciproca che ha portato alla divulgazione nel nostro ambito gnomonico di questa meridiana di pregevole fattura. In linea di massima si tratta di una meridiana sferica con undici linee orarie temporali e tre linee solstiziali. E’ conservata ottimamente e non presenta particolari fregi sulla base. Sul retro, in prossimità del punto di convergenza delle linee orarie, è visibile un foro che serviva probabilmente all’incastro dello gnomone orizzontale. Una inclinazione inspiegabile, ovviamente. Ma non è tutto, dai calcoli effettuati, Huttig ha rilevato che la superficie concava della meridiana non risulterebbe essere una sfera, ma un “ellissoide rotazionale”! E Huttig si chiedeva: “Perché un ingegnere avrebbe scelto una forma cosi’ complicata? Si puo’ pensare che ci fosse un’altra meridiana veramente sferica prima che fosse “cancellata” (rubbed out) per qualche ragione ottenendo come risultato questa nuova forma? Il mio parere è molto piu’ semplice ed ho sempre pensato che la lavorazione artigianale di queste meridian non si astata semper semplice e precisa. Io sarei piu’ propenso nel credere che si tratti di un errore di costruzione, non so quanto rilevante ai fini della lettura dell’ora sulla meridiana, ma non credo che influisca notevolmente.

generalInformation.description: Broken dial face, no gnomon remains. The sundial is the corona of a three figures sculpture of Zeus, Hercules and Atlas.

Fu scoperta dall’équipe dell’Atelier Municipal d’Archéologie de Lunel-Viel (Claude Raynaud, CNRS), nei materiali di rimpiazzo utilizzati per una strada del II secolo d.C. come pure quindi la stessa meridiana. Il tracciato orario è del tipo classico, ma le linee sono tracciate su una superficie concava, né sferica, né conica e sono limitate dalle linee solstiziali. Inolgtre il tracciato non è molto regolare, come sarebbe nel caso di una superficie sferica o conica e le linee attorno al sorgere e tramontare del sole son omolto piu’ ristrette rispetto a quelle meridiane centrali. Ciò è dovuto alla strana forma concava della superficie che tende a far prendere alle linee delle forme quasi ellittiche o a forma d’uovo. La latitudine calcolata da Parés è compresa tra 43 e 44 gradi che corrisponde bene a quella di Lune-Viel.

Ciò è dovuto alla strana forma concava della superficie che tende a far prendere alle linee delle forme quasi ellittiche o a forma d’uovo. La latitudine calcolata da Parés è compresa tra 43 e 44 gradi che corrisponde bene a quella di Lune-Viel.

generalInformation.description: Stranamente questa meridiana sferica, molto bella nel suo stile, anche se mancante per quasi una metà, è rimasta sconosciuta. Gli autori che l’hanno divulgata attraverso un sito internet non hanno riportato l’anno in cui fu rinvenuta durante gli scavi di Paestum. Probabilmente è stata portata alla luce di recente, quasi sicuramente dopo la pubblicazione della Gibbs (che non si avrebbe fatto sfuggire questa occasione). Si tratta dell’unico esemplare ritrovato in un’area archeologica tra le piu’ importanti e molto vicina a Pompei. “La sproporzione con i ritrovamenti di Pompei e di altri siti archeologici anche meno importanti (es. Ostia e Aquileia), fa pensare che Paestum, nel corso dei secoli, abbia subito inumerevoli razzie, ma fa anche sperare in futuri ritrovamenti”, scrive Giovanni Pititto, autore del testo inserito nel sito che divulga la meridiana. La meridiana si presenta di ottima fattura e di uno stile che non è stato ancora ben definito. Quello di ricavare spazi orari in rilievo nella conca sferica è forse solo un abbellimento estetico e non è nemmeno molto comune nei tanti orologi ritrovati. Si noti a tal proposito la somiglianza di stile con la meridiana di Petra anch’essa con gli spazi orari in rilievo, sebbene diversa come manufattura architettonica. Questa bella meridiana è tronca per buona parte della superficio superiore (oltre la metà sul bordo superiore). Si contano 7 spazi orari i quali, al contrario di come scrive Pititto nel suo testo, non sono regolari “di uguale ampiezza”, come mostra evidente la foto, ma piu’ larghi nelle ore vicino al mezzogiorno e piu’ stretti tra le altre linee orarie. Forse si tratta di un tracciato non troppo preciso. Ben evidente è la curva equinoziale la cui presenza indica certamente che era presente anche quella del solstizio invernale e quindi quella del solstizio estivo corrispondente al taglio della concavità sferica inferiore. “Il Basamento, che presenta un grosso foro semicircolare, è ornato da due animali accovacciati con la testa mancante. Al centro si trova una sfera fasciata da tre anelli disposti a 120°”, è la descrizione finale di Pititto che ringrazio per le informazioni e per la gentile concessione del materiale qui pubblicato.

generalInformation.description: Although made of travertine, a stone that by nature is porous, it is reasonably well conserved, apart from having both upper corners broken. The seating for the gnomon, a rectangular incision of 30 x 15 x 5 mm, is still visible (see figure), as are the solstice curves, the equinox curve, and eleven hour lines. The workmanship is rather rough and the block is not squared well. The edge of the upper horizontal face would seem to be a circle, although the dimensions available do not provide enough evidence for us to be sure of this. However, the noon hour line, which is a generator of the cone, is perfectly straight.

dialfaces.description: The seating for the gnomon, a rectangular incision of 30 x 15 x 5 mm, is still visible (see figure), as are the solstice curves, the equinox curve, and eleven hour lines. The workmanship is rather rough and the block is not squared well. The edge of the upper horizontal face would seem to be a circle, although the dimensions available do not provide enough evidence for us to be sure of this. However, the noon hour line, which is a generator of the cone, is perfectly straight.  It has one anomalous feature for a conical sundial: the distance on the noon hour line between the winter solstice curve and the equinox curve is equal to the distance between the latter and the summer solstice curve. This precludes the mathematical calculation of the angle between the axis of the cone and the noon hour line, which is a generator of the cone, and it is therefore impossible to calculate the intended latitude. The angle between the oblique front of the dial and the rear vertical plane is about 40°, not very different from the latitude of Vulci, which is nearly 42°. The hour lines divide the solstice and equinox curves at points that are only approximately equidistant. To calculate the intended latitude with the other usual methods  the average values of these arcs can be used, giving about 66° from each solstice curve, very different from the true latitude of  Vulci. The presumably arbitrary positions of the hour lines seem to support the thesis of Hüttig, according to which the day curves of conical sundials were often traced as auxiliary elements, divided into twelve equal intervals and uniting the corresponding points with straight arcs, in order to obtain the hour lines and not to represent the real solstice and equinox curves. The conclusion is that the conical sundial from Vulci was not built with great precision.

generalInformation.note: Probably from the remains of the settlement of Vulci, the ancient-Etruscan town Volci that came under Roman domination in the third century B.C

generalInformation.description: La meridiana è stata conservata fino al 1991 nei locali della Chiesa di S. Maria in Camucia. “Dopo una mostra sulle meridiane in Todi e una pubblicazione su una rivista tuderte”, la meridiana è stata prelevata da funzionari della Soprintendenza Archeologica di Perugia. Fu rinvenuta verso il 1931 da Monsignor Petrucci, parroco del Tempio del Crocefisso, presso la città di Ponte Rio (Todi), in prossimità del torrente detto “Rio”. Si dice che la meridiana fosse usata dalle lavandaie per batterci i panni sopra. E’ in buono stato di conservazione. Presenta gli spigoli superiori danneggiati e la zona del buco che conteneva lo gnomone. Nella cavità vi sono incise 11 linee orarie temporarie attraversate dalle tre linee di declinazione per il solstizio invernale, gli ezionozi e il solstizio estivo. Due fregi in rilievo sui lati, appena sotto la cavità conica, ed un altro disegno al centro decorano questa bella meridiana. Tali segni sono stati riscontrati su una tomba di Tarquinia e sullo scudo di un guerriero etrusco di Volterra.

generalInformation.description: It is an example of the rare case where the conical surface is cut quite perfectly, but all the geometrical details were added with poor accuracy. The raw basalt block must have approximated to a cube of an edge length of about 450 mm. Together with four further specimens from Syria and one from Saudi Arabia, this marks the eastern limit of provenance of all the nearly three hundred known Greco-Roman sundials.

dialfaces.description: It is an example of the rare case where the conical surface is cut quite perfectly, but all the geometrical details were added with poor accuracy. Accordingly, an ideal cone can be fitted with a half-aperture of 24° and an axis inclined at 22° to the cut horizontal bottom plane and the top plane of the piece. The deviation of this inclination from the local latitude of 33° is still more evident if one considers the 17° by which the oblique southern front plane is inclined to the vertical, thus differing by 5° from the perpendicular to the axis. Furthermore, the only inscribed curve (see figure) intersecting the eleven hour lines defines a plane even closer to the vertical and so this by no means represents a seasonal day line. No explanation can be offered for this other than that we have an imitation of such a line (or of an auxiliary one according to Hüttig's general interpretation). All the angles mentioned are uncertain by about ±2°, mainly due to the loss of reference accuracy because the southern shoulders of the piece have been broken off. Another oddity may be seen in the fact that the joining point of the eleven hour lines lies considerably below the upper edge of the surface, where no trace of a gnomon-mounting is visible. A gnomon at that level would be geometrically acceptable but it would interfere with the reading of the first and last daily hours, while a gnomon at a higher level would avoid this problem but would impair the accuracy at any hour.

generalInformation.description: A Hellenistic sundial not contained in the standard catalogue by Gibbs. This example is unique in being made of plaster, in its small size, and in having a shadow-receiving surface of negative, roughly hyperboloidal curvature.

dialfaces.description: A Hellenistic sundial not contained in the standard catalogue by Gibbs. This example is unique in being made of plaster, in its small size, and in having a shadow-receiving surface of negative, roughly hyperboloidal curvature. As is shown by the location of the eleven hour lines, the lost gnomon was undoubtedly placed as usual within the horizontal upper plane, and the twelve hour segments show equal breadth with an accuracy netter than average. The maximum indivation of season possible with this design would have been achieved with a gnomon tip adjusted to the centre of the circular edge line, so as to have its shadow on the face during the winter half of the year and off the face in summer. Although these features are satisfactorily represented, the sundial has a minor defect in that the horizontal top surface as described above is clearly not parallel to the plane at the bottom of the base, a fact that can be explained only as a mistake or as a subsequent adaption to an oblique support.

generalInformation.note: Found at Aphrodite temple. Published by Chrysantos Kanellopoulos.

archive.holderInstitution: Museo di Storia Naturale del Mediterraneo

generalInformation.description: La meridiana oggetto di questo studio è stata ottenuta utilizzando un blocco di marmo bianco di tipo saccaroide a grana fi nissima e senza alcuna venatura, con caratteristiche simili a quello apuano. Sulla superfi cie concava si conservano le tracce della martellatura, tecnica con la quale la stessa è stata ottenuta, consistenti in coppelle di diametro compreso tra 1 e 1,5 mm. La superfi cie del manufatto è completamente alterata per azione chimica subita durante la permanenza nel terreno ed ha assunto una colorazione grigiastra molto chiara. Il reperto mostra diverse abrasioni provocate in tempi recenti dai mezzi meccanici durante le arature del terreno. Queste scalfi tture permettono di constatare lapurezza ed il colore originale della materia prima. Sebbene la meridiana sia piuttosto danneggiata lungo i bordi, su quello superiore si è conservato parte dell’alloggio dello gnomone.

dialfaces.description: L’oggetto conserva poco più della metà della superfi cie concava sulla quale sono state incise le linee orarie. Delle undici linee orarie che dovevano dividere la meridiana in dodici parti (le ore temporarie in uso nel mondo greco e romano descritte nell’introduzione) se ne vedono solo cinque, tra cui quella del mezzodì. Sono ben visibili le linee dei solstizi e degli equinozi, che attraversano le linee orarie: come di consueto in questo tipo di manufatti la curva del solstizio d’estate coincide con il bordo lavorato dell’oggetto. L’alloggio delle linee orarie è stato realizzato in modo sferico. Nella parte inferiore si nota il taglio della pietra che, in questo tipo di manufatti costruiti ad arte, corrisponde alla latitudine del luogo. Dallo studio del reperto (Fig. 4) appare una inclinazione che collocherebbe la meridiana ad una latitudine di circa 37°, non compatibile con il luogo del rinvenimento o, in generale, con la fascia del centro Italia, ma con l’area del Sud Italia o della Grecia.

generalInformation.description: A tripartite sundial from Tell Er Ras, Zeus Temple, Mt Gerizim, (by R. J. Bull, Drew University, USA). Bull: The sundial, formed from a block of local limestone 440 mm long, 300 mm wide and 325 mm high, has suffered damage, especially to its top and back. As a result, most of its dimensions and many of its details have been determined. At the back of the limestone block two spaces, each in the shape of a quarter-sphere, one at either end of the block, have been hollowed out of the stone. This triple sundial probably functioned in the following manner:  If the limestone block was positioned so that Sundial 3 was oriented to the east and Sundial 2 to the west, Sundial 1 would face north. The rising sun would cause two shadows to be cast, one by the gnomon on the face of Sundial 1, the other by the gnomon of Sundial 3. Both shadows would move from the first hour, A, progressively through the six hours of the morning until the sixth hour, noon, vertical shadows would lie along the lines marked by the numeral F. Observer A facing south and looking at the north face of Sundial 1 would in the course of the morning hours see the gnomon shadow progress from its right to its left, while at the same time Observer B facing north and looking at Sundial 3 would see the gnomon shadow progress in the course of the morning hours, from left to right. As the afternoon progressed the shadow on the dial of Sundial 1 would continue to progress from right to left through the last hour of the day. At the same time Sundial 3 would increasingly fall into shadow whereas from the hour of noon, the gnomon shadow on Sundial 2 would begin to mark the afternoon hours moving from left to right as viewed by Observer B.

dialfaces.description: By cutting through the length of the block at an angle of 33" from the vertical (fig. 3, photograph 3) a surface 44 cm. long by 39 cm. wide was formed (fig. 1). On this reclined surface at approximately 30 cm. above the projected bottom edge of the stone a horizontal line, AB, at least 41 cm in length, was scribed. Below line AB and at its center, point Z, three semi-circles with radii of 11 cm, 12.5 cm, and 20.5 cm, respectively, were cut. At every 15" of arc around the 1800 of the semi-circles, lines radiating from point Z were scribed between the semi-circumference of the 11 cm radius semicircle and that of the 20.5 cm radius semicircle. In this manner eleven scribed lines divided the area between the innermost and outermost semicircles into twelve equal sectors. Vertical line GC, 21 cm long, was scribed perpendicular to line AB (fig. 1). At point G, 3 cm below point Z, a 1 cm square, 4 cm deep hole with sides perpendicular to the reclined surface had been cut (fig. 3). The hole was partly covered by a flow of lead, in the center of which had been formed a square hole approximately 1 cm on each side. It seems clear that at one time a metal gnomon had been fitted into the hole and had stood perpendicular to the 33" reclined surface. As one faces the reclined surface with its inverted and regularly divided semicircles which form the face of Sundial 1 (figs. 1 and 2, photograph 1), traces of ten inscribed Greek capital letters, 1.5 cm high, can be seen to the right of each of the scribed lines, radiating from point Z at intervals of 15 of arc.
dialfaces.inscriptions: The Greek letters, or more properly Greek numerals, are positioned midway between the semi-circumferences of the middle and outermost of the semicircles. Damage to the stone has caused the loss of part of the scribed lines as well as one and perhaps two of the numerals. Read from right to left, facing Sundial I as in figures I and 2 and photograph 1, the numerals were  [Α], Β, Γ, Δ, Ε, Φ, Ζ, Η, Θ, Ι, ΙΑ  and perhaps [IB]. The first numeral, A, is missing. The fifth numeral, E, has a rounded rather than a square shape. Of the sixth numeral, only a horizontal stroke and part of a vertical stroke remain. Since the vau or digamma may be represented by  c, x, or F the reconstruction of the numeral in the form F   given above has been based on the length and relative position of the extant vertical stroke. In the  Α  of the eleventh numeral,   ΙΑ,   there is no clear evidence of a cross stroke. The twelfth numeral,  ΙΒ,   if it ever existed, has been completely destroyed. Unlike the others, numerals  Β, Γ,    and  Δ  are oriented with their vertical axes perpendicular to the radiate lines.

dialfaces.description: The quarter sphere of Sundial 2 has suffered much greater damage than that of Sundial 3, but there are on its surface lines enough to indicate that the pattern originally inscribed thereon was a mirror image of that already described for Sundial 3. Damage to the stone has caused the loss of the exact location of the gnomon at each end as well as the method of their attachment. They were probably fixed perpendicular to the plane represented by the back of the limestone block at or near points X and Y where the radiate lines converge in each sundial. On each of the concave surfaces of Sundial 2 and Sundial 3 half of the dial pattern found on the reclining surface of Sundial 1 had been scribed except that the enumeration of the hours was reversed.
dialfaces.inscriptions: No numerals have survived on Sundial 2 (photograph 3), but it seems probable that the numerals beside the lines which radiate from point X (fig. 5a) originally read from left to right   Ζ, Η, Ο, Ι, ΙΑ    and perhaps   ΙΒ.

dialfaces.description: At the back of the limestone block two spaces, each in the shape of a quarter sphere, one at either end of the block, have been hollowed out of the stone (figs. 3, 5a, 5b; photograph 2). The vertical axes of these quarter spheres are the intersections of a vertical plane representing the back of the limestone block and the two vertical planes representing the ends of the block. Damage in the past has caused the loss of between 1/3 and 1/2 of each of the 24 cm diameter quarter spheres and the loss of almost all of the lines and numerals once inscribed on their concave surfaces (figs. 4 and 6, photographs 2, 3 and 4). The quarter sphere to the right as one faces the back of the limestone block, Sundial 3 (figs. 4, 5b and 6, photographs 2 and 4), has on its extant surface the remains of five inscribed lines, all of which radiate from point Y at the edge of the quarter sphere. Point Y may be defined as that place on the concave surface of the quarter sphere of Sundial 3 where the vertical plane representing the end of the limestone block and a horizontal plane parallel to and 17 cm above the plane representing the bottom surface of the limestone block intersect (fig. 5b). All five scribed lines radiate at equal angles and divide the lower and larger segment of the surface of the quarter sphere into six sectors. These six sectors and the lines which define them are in turn intersected by three lines approximately 5 cm apart. The three equidistant intersecting lines can perhaps best be visualized as intersections on the quarter spherical surface by three parallel planes 5 cm apart, all inclined at an angle of 33" from the vertical. These three planes, therefore, are parallel to the reclined plane represented by the surface of Sundial 1.
dialfaces.inscriptions: Traces of three numerals  Ε, Δ, Γ  all 1.5 cm high, are found on the surface of Sundial 3 to the left of three of the five radiating lines. No numeral has been preserved to the left of, and adjacent to, the edge of the quarter sphere which is also the end of the limestone block, but to the left of the first radiate scribed line preserved is the numeral  Ε,   and to the left of the second radiate scribed line a   Δ   and to the left of the third radiate scribed line a  Γ . The numerals in the six sectors on the curved surface of Sundial 3 read from right to left:   [Φ], Ε, Δ, Γ, [Β], [Α].  Of numerals  Α, Β   and   Φ   there is no trace. Numerals  Ε, Δ, Γ    are oriented so that their vertical axes are perpendicular to the adjacent scribed radiate lines (fig. 4, photograph 4).

generalInformation.inscriptions: The Greek letters, or more properly Greek numerals, are positioned midway between the semi-circumferences of the middle and outermost of the semicircles. Damage to the stone has caused the loss of part of the scribed lines as well as one and perhaps two of the numerals. Read from right to left, facing Sundial 1 as in figures 1 and 2 and photograph 1, the numerals were  [Α], Β, Γ, Δ, Ε, Φ, Ζ, Η, Θ, Ι, ΙΑ  and perhaps [IB]. The first numeral, A, is missing. The fifth numeral, E, has a rounded rather than a square shape. Of the sixth numeral, only a horizontal stroke and part of a vertical stroke remain. Since the vau or digamma may be represented by  ϛ, ξ, ορ Φ  the reconstruction of the numeral in the form F given above has been based on the length and relative position of the extant vertical stroke. In the A of the eleventh numeral, IA, there is no clear evidence of a cross stroke. The twelfth numeral, IB, if it ever existed, has been completely destroyed. Unlike the others, numerals B, G, and D are oriented with their vertical axes perpendicular to the radiate lines.

generalInformation.note: Found in the ancient city of Jerusalem by Nakhman Avigad.

generalInformation.description: At the top had been a horizontal rod of metal, a gnomon, which cast its shadow on the concave dial. The stub of the rod is still stuck in the stone. Such rods were known as the "point of the sundial" in the Mishnah (Kelim 12,5; Eduyot 3,8). Our sundial is ornamented on one side with a series of rosettes carved in bas-relief. The style and "woodcarving" technique of the rosettes are identical with the ornamentation commonly found on the Jewish ossuaries of the Second Temple period. This small, portable sundial is unique in its ornamentation and rare in its size.

dialfaces.description: The concave dial is divided by incised lines into twelve radial segments.

Fragment.

In Villa A of the Oplontis excavation area, called Villa di Poppea after Nero's wife, a conical sundial was found in 1973. It is now kept in the depository. Oplontis was a residential city between Pompeii and Herculanum, very small but with large villas. It was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79. The modern name of the city is Torre Annunziata. The dial is conical, of white marble, and in a good state of conservation with only a small part broken off at the right upper edge. Its decoration is of a very common type with two six-petalled rosettes on either side of a crescent moon on the oblique front surface. A metallic gnomon is still present on its upper side, the length of which is 85 mm.

dialfaces.description: The face shows the eleven hour lines, the equinox and the two solstitial curves. These three day curves are divided by approximately equidistant points of intersection with the hour lines. On the noon hour line, the distance of the equinox curve from the winter and summer solstitial curves are 44mm and 72mm, respectively. Applying commonly used methods of calculation, we find that the angle between the axis of the cone and the generator of the conical surface is 30.5° and the resulting original gnomon length is 88mm. On the basis of these data the intended latitude is 40°, agreeing admirably with the 40.8° of the site. Consequently, the conical sundial from Villa A of Oplontis is of very good accuracy.

generalInformation.description: Two rather inexactly made miniature spherical dials in stone can be mentioned. One, in the Archaeological Museum of Rhodes, the other, in Syracuse is almost complete.

dialfaces.description: Two rather inexactly made miniature spherical dials in stone can be mentioned. One, in the Archaeological Museum of Rhodes, the other, in Syracuse is almost complete.

generalInformation.description: La meridiana ad emiciclo trovò un´ampia diffusion come orolgio solare el mondo Greco-romano. Derivò da una genial intuizione del babilonese Beroso (IV sec a.C.): l´emisphericum che consisteva in uns semisfera che riproduceva  rovesciata la colta celste con al centro uno gnomon vertical di lunghezza pari  al raggio della sfera. In seguito al ritrovamento di un frammento di meridian ad emiciclo (circa la metà) avvenuta a Mardimago in località Bernadetta (sito A 39), il Gruppo Astrofili Polesani è stato incaricato a riconstruine un  modello che ne ritoducesse l´intera semiazza originale. La suddivisione oratia dell´emiciclo venne effettuata in portionei uguali die 15 ognina perché così sembrava essere stat effettuata sull´originale ritrovato e così appariva nelle diapositive di alcune meridiane antiche.

dialfaces.description: It shows the eleven hour lines, the equinox and the two solstitial curves, all quite irregular. The solstitial curves are almost equidistant from the equinox line, as theory requires, 18 namely 245mm and 250mm. The diameter of the equinoctial circle is therefore 451mm. Applying commonly used methods of calculation, we find that the intended latitude is 40.5°, to be compared with the 40.8° of Torre Annunziata. We conclude that the spherical sundial from Villa B of Oplontis is of good accuracy.

generalInformation.note: Found in 1982 near Villa B, called Villa di Crasso.

generalInformation.description: Three small fragments (see figure) of a light limestone vertical deviating sundial, now in the City Antiquarium of Guidonia Montecelio, were found on different occasions in the countryside of Guidonia, a small town near Tivoli. The fractures of two of these pieces match, so they can be put together, while the third piece is from a different part of the sundial. The reassembled fragment is 115 mm high, 200 mm wide and 7 mm deep. The dimensions of the detached fragment are 146 mm by 16 mm by 27 mm. The noon hour line is completely missing, so it is difficult to make the usual calculations to determine the intended latitude. Consequently, the author has attempted an inverse procedure from the one normally followed when studying a sundial: the object was reconstructed starting from the reasonable hypothesis that it was built for the latitude of 42°, the latitude in which it was found. The angle between the equinox line and the upper edge of the fragment, assumed to be horizontal, was measured and found to be 40°, from which a deviation 49° west can be deduced. On the basis of these figures, the author made a drawing of a vertical deviating sundial which would seem to correspond quite well if the perpendicular height of the gnomon was about 130 mm. In the example, the winter hyperbola appears higher than that calculated astronomically, a situation that is not rare in ancient sundials of imprecise workmanship. Through the reconstruction it was possible to identify, with good approximation, the position originally occupied by the third fragment, which contains a small part of the summer solstice curve. The shape of the cut stone slab must have been something like a triangle, with two straight sides ¬- the upper horizontal and the noon vertical - and the third an arc approximately parallel to the summer solstice curve. It is clear, in fact, from the third fragment that this arc is not the result of a fracture but was carefully worked by the builder, who engraved an X in the concavity, rotated by 90° and delimited by two small vertical bars.

generalInformation.description: A light-colored marble vertical deviating sundial, in a good state of conservation (see figure), was found on the site of some Roman buildings. The sundial is inscribed with the winter solstice curve, completely preserved; the summer solstice curve, about half of which remains; and the equinox line, almost all of which remains. There are six hour lines. The usual methods of calculation give an intended latitude of about 39°, little differing from that of the place where it was found, namely 42°. To judge from the slope of the equinox line, the face of the sundial probably deviated from the prime vertical by 36° west. The length of the gnomon, according to the calculations, was 58 mm. The test of the distance along the equinox line between the noon line and the first hour after noon gave the following results: calculated 35 mm, measured 44 mm. Taking everything into account, the conclusion is that this sundial was built with a relatively good degree of accuracy.

generalInformation.description: A Matelica si trova un raro modello di orologio solare in marmo bianco risalente, con incisioni, segni e scritture greche, detto “globo di Matelica”. // Il Globo o Sfera fu rinvenuto, nel 1985, durante le fasi di consolidamento del Palazzo del Governo, nel pieno centro storico di Matelica. Il Globo è costituito da una sfera, del diametro di 29 cm., di marmo greco cristallino. Su di essa sono incisi centri concentrici, linee, archi, lettere e parole greche. Il Globo è un antichissimo orologio solare, adoperato per fare calcoli astrologici, astronomici e cronologici. E’ un piccolo “computer di pietra” che può essere usato, con buona approssimazione, per calcolare le ore del giorno dal sorgere del sole, la data di Equinozi e Solstizi, il calendario e l’entrata del sole nelle varie costellazioni zodiacali. Il Globo è una sorta di meridiana e deve essere esposto correttamente alla luce per poter offrire dati corretti: le zone di luce e di ombra vanno ad intersecare i segni e le linee incise sulla superficie  fornendo risposte corrette. Gordon and Reynolds: Another extremely rare device from Umbria, comparable only to an example from Prosymna found in 1935 (SEG 11.304), served a similar purpose, to give the month and hour, but seems to have worked with a gnomon. It consists of a marble sphere of about 29.3 cm diameter, which was fixed to a base at one 'pole' and oriented in the proper direction for the latitude of Matilica. The equator is marked round the circumference, with a meridian at right angles to it through the upper 'pole'. Parallel to the equator and somewhat below the pole, runs a line of thirteen equidistant holes each marked with a numeral: its centre-point, where it crosses the meridian, is no. 12; to the left are the numerals 11, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6; to the right 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Midway between this sequence and the equator are three concentric circles bisected by the meridian line. This diagram is marked in Greek with the names of the Zodiacal signs, at the top the winter solstice in Capricorn; then the pairs of signs separated by the meridian line; at the bottom the summer solstice in Cancer (this text alone is available at AE 1998: 426). Given its small size, it was probably used, like the skaphe, in a private house.

generalInformation.description: Il est en assez bon état de conservation, malgré l’absence des ailes latérales, brisées, et du gnomon, dont on devine l’emplacement par une cavité de trois centimètres de profondeur.

dialfaces.description: Il est en assez bon état de conservation, malgré l’absence des ailes latérales, brisées, et du gnomon, dont on devine l’emplacement par une cavité de trois centimètres de profondeur. Il présente onze lignes horaires gravées nettement dans la pierre, et trois courbes de déclinaisons.

generalInformation.note: Découvert en 1972 par F. Margenat et P. Roura lors des fouilles de la propriété de Can Feliu, sur le site d’une possible villa romaine.

generalInformation.description: Située dans le canton d’Òdena, Espelt est une villa romaine dont les fouilles ont permis la découverte d’un fragment de cadran solaire sphérique (conique selon E. Farré i Olivé). Du cadran, n’est conservé que la partie orientale de la surface réceptrice. On n’observe donc que les lignes horaires de l’après-midi.

dialfaces.description: Du cadran, n’est conservé que la partie orientale de la surface réceptrice. On n’observe donc que les lignes horaires de l’après-midi. Le fragment ne présente aucune courbe solsticiale ou équinoxiale.

dimensions.note: Le cadran complet devait mesurer approximativement.
Le cadran complet devait mesurer approximativement.

generalInformation.description: L’instrument, creusé dans un bloc de grès local, est fort érodé. Les extrémités frontales et latérales ont entièrement disparues, le gnomon est bien évidemment manquant, mais son emplacement est encore perceptible.

dialfaces.description: Les extrémités frontales et latérales ont entièrement disparues, le gnomon est bien évidemment manquant, mais son emplacement est encore perceptible. Le cadran ne possède toujours pas de courbes de déclinaisons horaires (équinoxiales et solsticiales) et présente le réseau habituel des onze lignes temporelles.

generalInformation.description: Sa forme est peu commune dans le corpus des cadrans romains, et sa réalisation technique très négligée. Ainsi, il est difficile d’en définir la typologie, que nous laisserons volontairement «indéterminée».

dialfaces.description: Sa forme est peu commune dans le corpus des cadrans romains, et sa réalisation technique très négligée. Ainsi, il est difficile d’en définir la typologie, que nous laisserons volontairement «indéterminée». L’arc gravé non loin de l’emplacement du gnomon est probablement décoratif, il ne s’agit absolument pas de la courbe du solstice d’hiver. Les lignes horaires sont gravées de façon irrégulières, et ne sont pas espacées logiquement ni géométriquement. Il en résultait ainsi un fonctionnement très approximatif, loin des «canons» gnomoniques de l’époque.

generalInformation.description: Il s’agit d’un cadran conique. Le gnomon a disparu, ainsi que les ailes latérales. La face frontale n’est ni perpendiculaire à l’axe de la terre, ni à l’axe du cône. L’ensemble est donc très approximatif.

dialfaces.description: On retrouve les onze lignes horaires ainsi qu’un cercle intermédiaire, qui, comme pour le cadran de Vilanova, évoque plus une représentation de la ligne équinoxiale qu’une réelle courbe de déclinaison utilisable. Le centre du cadran n’est pas situé dans l’axe du cône comme il devrait l’être mais à la base du gnomon L’angle entre la face frontale et la verticale est de 29°, ce qui ne correspond pas à celui de Mazaracín, à peu près 40°. La face frontale n’est ni perpendiculaire à l’axe de la terre, ni à l’axe du cône. L’ensemble est donc très approximatif.

generalInformation.note: Il a été retrouvé lors d’une prospection dans une carrière nommé Arroyo de Mazarracín, probablement sur le site d’une installation romaine encore non identifiée. L’environnement géographique proche est en effet très riche en villae romaines.

generalInformation.description: Il s’agit d’un fragment de cadran conique. Seule la partie occidentale, présentant les lignes post-meridiem, est conservée. Il ne semble pas y avoir de lignes solsticiales ou équinoxiales.

dialfaces.description: Seule la partie occidentale, présentant les lignes post-meridiem, est conservée. Il ne semble pas y avoir de lignes solsticiales ou équinoxiales.

generalInformation.description: Conical sundial with central bukranion at base.

Il s’agit d’un fragment de cadran solaire sphérique découvert à Caesaraugusta et conservé au musée du Théâtre de Saragosse. On peut distinguer sur le fragment les courbes de déclinaisons. J. M. Raya Román suppose une utilisation privée plus que publique en prenant en considération la taille de l’objet, mais cela reste purement conjecturel.

dialfaces.description: On peut distinguer sur le fragment les courbes de déclinaisons.

generalInformation.description: Réalisé en bronze, il mesure 130 mm de diamètre et 4 mm d’épaisseur. Bien qu’érodé légèrement, on distingue en bordure d’une des faces de l’objet une série de noms de provinces romaines, ainsi que celui de la cité d’Alexandrie. La liste débute à Alexand[ria] et s’arrête à la Britannia Inf[erior]. Entre ces deux points, on peut lire V I IVL et VII IAN, inscriptions séparées par six lignes circulaires parallèles. L’intérieur du disque est gravé des latitudes respectives à chaque région. Les problèmes soulevés par les noms des provinces et les latitudes données ont été étudiés par J. Arce.

generalInformation.description: This sundial has a surface which is separated in 12 parts representing 12 hours of the day. More particularly, the sundial consists of a hyperbola tracing the shadows path at the winter solstice, a second one for the summer solstice, and a straight east-west line in between marking the equinoctial shadows.

dialfaces.description: This sundial has a surface which is separated in 12 parts representing 12 hours of the day. More particularly, the sundial consists of a hyperbola tracing the shadows path at the winter solstice, a second one for the summer solstice, and a straight east-west line in between marking the equinoctial shadows. A line from the base of the gnomon to the south of the dial running due north denotes noontime. The hyperbola is centered on this noon line. The winter hyperbola opens to the north, the summer hyperbola to the south. In addition to the center noon line, additional oblique lines are added on either side to denote the hours of daylight before and after noon.

generalInformation.note: Archaeologist of the 16th Ephorate of Prehistoric and Classical Antiquities, Betina Tsigarida, specialist in the area of Chalkidiki, was the one to find the sundial.

Frammento di presunta meridiana di epoca romana, conservato al Museo della Bonifica di San Donà di Piave. Reperto segnalato da Renis Ridolfo e presentato nel blog http://digilander.libero.it/rossi7871/VE0126.htm Dall'user "rossi7871". Sono visibili parte di 4 linee orarie e di due curve di declinazione corrispondenti al solstizio invernale e agli equinozi. Il tracciamento delle linee lascia pensare ad un orologio di fattura abbastanza modesta e non è escluso che posa trattarsi di un reperto di epoca molto tarda, forse anche bizantina, o addirittura altomedievale.

generalInformation.description: Am 16. August 1998 wurde beim Abbruch eines neuzeitlichen Hauses in Eretria eine Sonnenuhr gefunden und gleichentags in das Museum verbracht. Die Sonnenuhr war als Baumaterial in dem modernen Haus wiederverwendet worden, worauf auch die Beschädigungen auf der Vorderseite des ansonsten in seinem antiken Bestand erhaltenen Marmorblocks zurückzuführen sein dürften. Weitere Spuren der Verbauung finden sich vor allem auf der besser erhaltenen Schmalseite in Form einer feinen Mörtelschicht. Der Fundort liegt auf dem Grundstück 815 des Gesamtplanes von Eretria, im nördlichen Teil der Unterstadt, nahe dem Akropolis-Südfuss.  Da der Marmorblock, aus dem unsere Uhr gehauen wurde, mit Sicherheit als Import zu betrachten ist, kann zumindest nicht ausgeschlossen werden, dass die Uhr als Fertigstück nach Eretria kam. Es scheint daher sinnvoller, eine Herstellung der Uhr in Eretria und für Eretria zu postulieren. Dafür sprechen auch die nur sehr summarisch bearbeitete Rückseite und die deutlich von der ansonsten rechteckigen Gesamtform des Blockes abweichende Linienführung der Vorderseite. Dies scheint darauf hinzuweisen, dass die Sonnenuhr ursprünglich in einen architektonischen Zusammenhang eingegliedert war, was im übrigen auch für die Kegelsonnenuhr von Patras angenommen wurde.

generalInformation.description: Bei Grabungen ist ein Forschungsteam der Universität Basel im Tal der Könige in Oberägypten auf eine der ältesten altägyptischen Sonnenuhren gestossen. Mitarbeitende des Ägyptologischen Seminars unter der Leitung von Prof. Susanne Bickel machten den bedeutenden Fund bei der Freilegung eines Grabeingangs. Bei den diesjährigen Grabungsarbeiten fanden die Forschenden ein abgeflachtes Stück Kalkstein (sogenanntes Ostrakon), auf dem mit schwarzer Farbe ein Halbkreis mit zwölf Unterteilungen zu etwa 15 Grad aufgezeichnet wurde. Eine Vertiefung in der Mitte der rund 16 Zentimeter langen horizontalen Grundlinie diente der Befestigung eines Holz- oder Metallstifts, dessen Schatten die Stunden anzeigte. Kleine Punkte in der Mitte jedes Stundenwinkels dienten einer noch feineren Zeitmessung.  Der Fundort der Sonnenuhr befand sich im Bereich einiger Steinhütten, die im 13. Jahrhundert v. Chr. als Aufenthaltsort der am Bau der Königsgräber beschäftigten Arbeiter genutzt wurden. Möglicherweise diente die Sonnenuhr zur Messung ihrer Arbeitszeiten. Die Unterteilung des Sonnenlaufes in Stunden war jedoch auch ein zentraler Aspekt in den auf den Wänden der Königsgräber aufgezeichneten Jenseitsführern. Diese Jenseitsführer oder Unterweltbücher sind illustrierte Texte, welche die nächtliche Fahrt des Sonnengottes durch die Unterwelt in ihrer zeitlichen Abfolge beschreiben. Die Sonnenuhr könnte somit die Beobachtung und Visualisierung dieser Fahrt unterstützt haben.
From the necropolis in Sillyon. A funerary altar carried the sundial.

A unique clay object discovered at the site of Apollonia-Arsuf (Israel), which I claimed had been used as a horizontal (flat) portable sundial (horologium). The object is somewhat pentagonal, depicting a design that was incised (and partially stamped) on it prior to firing. Given its small dimensions, I rejected the idea that it could have served as a game board.  Due to its shallowness (some 0.15 m in depth) and design, I also rejected the possibility that it could have served as a mould for a metal object.

generalInformation.description: Garstang: A more curious object is carved in hard wood, representing the pylon of a temple with a dial below. Possibly a vertical dial placed upon a temple wall in the locality suggested the subject of this model, which has several points of special interest apart from the details of its execution. Museum: This little (9.8 cm long) pocket-sized wooden sundial is one of the treasures of our collection. It combines the segmented divisions of the sundial itself with the pylon entrance of a typical Egyptian temple.

dialfaces.description: It combines the segmented divisions of the sundial itself with the pylon entrance of a typical Egyptian temple.

generalInformation.description: The Egyptian sundial is a small ivory disk found at Gezer in Palestine. It dates from the reign of Merenptah (ca. 1224-1214 B.C.), whose cartouche it bears on the back of the disk and who is also pictured there making an offering to Thoth. Above the scene are the cartouches of the king. On the front of the disk we see the remains of 10 radiating lines (from a set that almost certainly originally contained 13 such lines, with the angles between two successive lines each being about 15degree ). The diameter of the dial is about 2 1/4 inches, with its center being evident from a small circle on the back. One can see from the edgewise view in Fig. III.55b that the disk was bored through its entire length so that the dial could be hung up by a chord passing through the bored channel. The inscriptions of figures and radial lines were originally filled with green enamel, some of which remains. Presumably, when intact, a style (i.e., a gnomon) must have been set into a hole in the center of the diameter of the semicircular dial face for the purpose of casting the angularly changing shadow.

dialfaces.description: Inschrift an den Linien
Inschrift an den Linien

In den Aufzeichnungen von Albert Rehm heißt es: „1905: Stück einer Säule von bläulichem Marmor. Im Felde beim Thor der heiligen Straße. H. 0,68, Durchm. 0,47: … sicher röm. Kaiserzeit.“ Rehm ist über den Fund zunächst so erstaunt, dass er die 31cm lange Mittagslinie zunächst  als belanglos ansieht und nie über sie publiziert. Erst viel später, am 4.2.1939, notiert er: „Es ist doch mehr als Spielerei, wie ich s. Z. glaubte, ein Hilfsmittel, den Mittagsschatten zu beobachten, um danach die Wasseruhr zu regulieren.“

generalInformation.description: δ̣ι̣ὰ̣ περιφερειῶν τῶν ἐφε[ξ]ῆς / τῶν διατεινουσῶν ἀπ' ἀνατολῶν ἐπὶ δύσεις / ἀπὸ τῆς ἑτέρας ἐπὶ τὴν ἑτέραν / μεθίσταται τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς / 5 ἐν  ἡμέραις τριάκοντα. ἀπὸ χειμερινῶν δὲ τροπῶν / ἐπὶ θερινὰς τροπὰς μεθιστάμενον / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς δι' / οὗ ἂν φέρηται / τῶν πρὸ μεσημβρίας Ζῳδίων / 10 ἐν τούτῳ τῷ Ζωδίῳ / σημαίνει τὸν ἥλιον εἶναι. / ἐπὶ τῶν ἰῶτα φερόμενον / σημαίνει ζεφύρου πνοήν. / ἀπὸ θερινῶν δὲ τροπῶν / 15 [ἐπ]ὶ χειμερινὰς τροπὰς μεθιστάμενον / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς δι' οὗ ἂν φέρηται / τῶν ἐκ μεσημβρίας Ζῳδίων / ἐν τούτῳ τῷ Ζωδίῳ / σημαίνει τὸν ἥλιον εἶναι. / 20 ἐπὶ τῶν ἰῶτα φερόμενον / σημαίνει Πλειάδος δύσιν. / ἑκάστης δὲ ἡμέρας / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς [   Durch die hintereinander folgenden Kreise, die von Osten zum Westen durchlaufen, wendet sich die Schattenspitze vom einen zum andern Kreis in 30 Tagen. Durch welches von den Tierkreiszeichen vor der Mittag(slinie) die Schattenspitze auf ihrem Weg von der Wintersonnenwende zur Sommersonnen-wende sich bewegt, in jenem Tierkreiszeichen, zeigt sie an, steht die Sonne. Wenn sie auf der gestrichelten Linie sich bewegt, zeigt sie das Wehen des Zephyrs an. Durch welches Tierkreiszeichen nach der Mittag(slinie) die Schattenspitze von der Sommerwende zur Winter-wende sich bewegt, in dem Tierkreiszeichen, zeigt sie (wieder) steht die Sonne. Wenn sie sich (wieder) auf der gestrichelten Linie befindet, zeigt sie den Unter-gang der Plejaden an. An jedem Tag zeigt die Spitze des Schattens (…) ." Es sind alleine diese Fragmente der Inschrift erhalten, auf die Crowfoot im Hof des graeco-römischen Museums in Alexandria stieß. "Si tratta di una delle più grandi meridiane coniche conservate nel Mediterraneo." "Le dimensioni del pezzo (tutti i simboli analoghi a quello della figura 3) sono: H=71 cm, Wr= ca. 88 cm (ricostruito), Dr=48 cm( ricostruito). Angolo  =59.60°? si adatta alla colatitudine di Alessandria con una precisione di un quarto di grado.Tre linee diurne sono visibili sulla parte conservata della superficie che riceve l’ombra. Il piede dell’orologio cade giù dritto senza alcun profilo decorativo." (Kosciuk 1992)

dialfaces.description: Es wurden nur Teile der Inschrift zur Uhr wurden 1901 am See Mariut nahe bei Alexandria (Ägypten) entdeckt.

Kommentar: δ̣ι̣ὰ̣ περιφερειῶν τῶν ἐφε[ξ]ῆς / τῶν διατεινουσῶν ἀπ' ἀνατολῶν ἐπὶ δύσεις / ἀπὸ τῆς ἑτέρας ἐπὶ τὴν ἑτέραν / μεθίσταται τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς / 5 ἐν  ἡμέραις τριάκοντα. ἀπὸ χειμερινῶν δὲ τροπῶν / ἐπὶ θερινὰς τροπὰς μεθιστάμενον / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς δι' / οὗ ἂν φέρηται / τῶν πρὸ μεσημβρίας Ζῳδίων / 10 ἐν τούτῳ τῷ Ζωδίῳ / σημαίνει τὸν ἥλιον εἶναι. / ἐπὶ τῶν ἰῶτα φερόμενον / σημαίνει ζεφύρου πνοήν. / ἀπὸ θερινῶν δὲ τροπῶν / 15 [ἐπ]ὶ χειμερινὰς τροπὰς μεθιστάμενον / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς δι' οὗ ἂν φέρηται / τῶν ἐκ μεσημβρίας Ζῳδίων / ἐν τούτῳ τῷ Ζωδίῳ / σημαίνει τὸν ἥλιον εἶναι. / 20 ἐπὶ τῶν ἰῶτα φερόμενον / σημαίνει Πλειάδος δύσιν. / ἑκάστης δὲ ἡμέρας / τὸ ἄκρον τῆς σκιᾶς [   Durch die hintereinander folgenden Kreise, die von Osten zum Westen durchlaufen, wendet sich die Schattenspitze vom einen zum andern Kreis in 30 Tagen. Durch welches von den Tierkreiszeichen vor der Mittag(slinie) die Schattenspitze auf ihrem Weg von der Wintersonnenwende zur Sommersonnen-wende sich bewegt, in jenem Tierkreiszeichen, zeigt sie an, steht die Sonne. Wenn sie auf der gestrichelten Linie sich bewegt, zeigt sie das Wehen des Zephyrs an. Durch welches Tierkreiszeichen nach der Mittag(slinie) die Schattenspitze von der Sommerwende zur Winter-wende sich bewegt, in dem Tierkreiszeichen, zeigt sie (wieder) steht die Sonne. Wenn sie sich (wieder) auf der gestrichelten Linie befindet, zeigt sie den Unter-gang der Plejaden an. An jedem Tag zeigt die Spitze des Schattens (…) una   meridiana   conica   “  from   Mariut”   vista   da   J.B.Crowfoot   nel   cortile   del   Museo   Greco   Romano   di   Alessandria 8 .   Il   pezzo  può,    con    ogni    probabilità    essere    identificato    con    una    frammentaria,    non    ancora    pubblicata,    meridiana    di    “provenienza  sconosciuta”    tenuta    in    uno    dei    magazzini    de llo    stesso    Museo 9 .    Si    tratta    di    una    delle    più    grandi    meridiane    coniche  conservate nel Mediterraneo.

generalInformation.description: Found 1986 by H. Williams (Canadian School) when excavating a Roman villa, dating to the 3rd or 4th century. The dial is lost, probably the result of an earthquake when parts of the apothiki fell down.

Description: Marbre blanc, très fortement patiné, devenu gris (l’identification de la pierre faite par Rubensohn, granit rouge, est erronée); pierre de mauvaise qualité, avec de nombreux petits graviers et trous; h. 27 cm, l. 38,3 cm, ép. 20,8 cm; légèrement endommagée; petites ébréchures sur les arêtes, la petite brèche à l’emplacement du style inexistant comblée de plâtre. L’ensemble est travaillé dans un bloc monolithe: le cadran même, sous forme d’un quart de sphère concave, «repose» sur une petite base plus large que celui-ci de 7 cm à l’avant du marbre. Le cadran porte un système de lignes gravées servant à indiquer la longueur et la direction de l’ombre (arachnè). Le système comprend trois lignes concentriques et onze lignes convergentes (horaires). Au sommet, une petite cavité permettant de fixer un style; le style (gnomon), originairement sans doute en bronze, aujourd’hui disparu. La ligne 1 de l’inscription gravée entre le cadran et la base; la ligne 2 sur la face avant de la base. Lettres gravées avec peu de soin; traces évidentes de couleur rouge au fond des lettres; apices esquissés. Alpha à barre en arceau, omicron un peu plus petit que les autres lettres, dans le sigma, les traits extérieurs tantôt obliques tantôt horizontaux. H. des lettres dans la ligne 1: env. 1,5 cm, dans la ligne 2: env. 1,0 cm. À proximité de l’endroit où était fixé le style une inscription à l’encre noire: «Beihilfe der Provinz». ---  Contexte et histoire de la decouverte et l'objet: Lieu et contexte de la découverte inconnus. Au début du XX s. vue par Arvanitakis, puis par Rubensohn dans le commerce des antiquités en Égypte. Achetée avant 1909 sur le marché des antiquités au Caire pour la  collection du Lyceum Hosianum à Braunsberg (no.  d’inv. 880), depuis 1947 au Musée National de Varsovie.

dialfaces.inscriptions: Translation: Héphaistion fils de Hérodès du dème Arsinoïs (a érigé  ce cadran solaire) après avoir exercé en l’an 29 la  charge de gymnasiarque (en le dédiant à) Hermès.  (Traduction française, texte original en grec ancient).

dialfaces.description: Sundial which stood on  a pedestal and bears an inscription: Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύδιος [Π]ολυπείθης ἐκ το̑ν ἰδίων ἀνέθηκεν. Tiberius Claudius Polypeithes hat (diese Uhr) auf eigene Kosten  aufgestellt. When an earthquake levelled the citiy in the senth century the column collapsed and broke in two and the sundial in seven pieces.

generalInformation.description: Excavated in a byzantine farm in 1995, the same farm, where in 1892 the copy of the lex hadriana de rudibus agris was found. Maybe there is a christian monogram in the centre, a cross combined with rho. Informations by Mariette de Vos Raaijmakers  Laboratorio di Archeologia e Scienze Affini  Università degli Studi di Trento.

Discovered in 1958. The lower part of the sundial is shaped like the head of a man of age with wild curly hair and a long full beard. This specific decoration might lead to the conclusion, that the sundial was positioned in a sanctuary, although the identity of the bearded man is not known.

dialfaces.description: Right upper corner destroyed. Eleven hourlines and two daycurves, a third one probably broken off or ending in the lower edge of the shadow area.

generalInformation.description: The Horologium Augusti was built under the reign of Augustus and dedicated 10 BCE. An almost 34 m high obelisk from Heliopolis, Egypt, called the Obelisk of Montecitorio, served as a gnomon.
